    Le tableau présente les progrès réalisés par Allianz en vue d'atteindre ses objectifs intermédiaires pour 2030 dans différents domaines, notamment ses propres opérations, ses investissements propriétaires et ses activités d'assurance. Les données incluent les valeurs de référence, les performances pour 2023 et 2024, ainsi que les écarts par rapport aux valeurs de référence en pourcentage. Les objectifs pour 2030 sont également indiqués, accompagnés des écarts prévus par rapport aux valeurs de référence.
    - Allianz Own Operations : Les émissions de CO₂ par employé ont diminué de 61,5 % par rapport à la valeur de référence, avec un objectif de réduction de 65 % d'ici 2030. - Proprietary Investments : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi ont baissé de 46,5 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 50 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ des entreprises cotées ont diminué de 50,7 %, avec un objectif similaire pour 2030. - Les émissions de CO₂ par m² pour l'immobilier sont en cours de suivi, avec un objectif d'environ 20 kg CO₂e/m² d'ici 2030. - Insurance : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros de primes d'assurance commerciale ont baissé de 11,7 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 45 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ pour le secteur automobile de détail ont diminué de 6,8 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 30 % d'ici 2030.

  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les **exigences de divulgation** concernant les politiques de rémunération et les systèmes d'incitation liés aux **objectifs de durabilité** pour les membres des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. Les colonnes incluent les intitulés **"Disclosure Requirement"**, **"Reference"** et **"Annotation"**, et les informations sont issues du **"Remuneration Report"** et de la section **"Determination of the remuneration system"**. Les points clés incluent : 1. Les **systèmes d'incitation** intègrent des objectifs de durabilité, notamment des cibles de décarbonisation pour les investissements, les assurances et les opérations internes, bien qu'aucun pourcentage fixe ne soit lié aux considérations climatiques. 2. Les **cibles spécifiques** incluent la satisfaction client (e.g., **digital Net Promoter Score**), l'engagement des employés (**Allianz Engagement Survey**) et la qualité du leadership, avec des aspects comportementaux comme l'intégrité et la réduction des émissions de CO2. 3. Environ **un tiers des facteurs de contribution individuels** est lié aux objectifs de durabilité, influençant la rémunération variable jusqu'à **14 %** positivement ou négativement, avec une portée totale de **28 %**. 4. Les **politiques de rémunération** sont approuvées et mises à jour au niveau de l'entreprise, mais certaines descriptions restent non détaillées. Le tableau met en évidence l'intégration des objectifs de durabilité dans les politiques de rémunération, tout en soulignant des lacunes dans certaines descriptions. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Disclosure Requirement Reference Annotation
    Incentive schemes and remuneration policies linked to sustainability matters for members of administrative, management, and supervisory bodies exist Remuneration Report Sustainability matters are included by incorporating them into the individual contribution factor of the target achievement (for BoM members). This extends to the decarbonization targets for proprietary investments, insurance, and own operations. However, there is no fixed percentage for remuneration linked to climate considerations. The remuneration of the members of the Supervisory Board does not factor in climate-related considerations and is not linked to our progress on decarbonization. A target achievement factor as well as a sustainability check factor is incorporated into the variable pay component.
    Description of key characteristics of incentive schemes Remuneration Report -
    Description of specific sustainability-related targets and (or) impacts used to assess performance of members of administrative, management, and supervisory bodies Remuneration Report Sustainability targets: Non-financial sustainability targets take into account customer satisfaction (e.g., digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS), employee engagement (e.g., Allianz Engagement Survey), and leadership quality. The individual leadership quality assessment process also includes a review of behavioral aspects, such as customer orientation, collaborative leadership, entrepreneurship, and trust (e.g., corporate social responsibility, integrity, diversity, and sustainability as measured by the greenhouse gas reduction of Allianz companies and by the development of a roadmap to reduce CO2 emissions in the context of capital allocation).
    Disclosure of how sustainability-related performance metrics are considered as performance benchmarks or included in remuneration policies Remuneration Report Please also note information on the Board of Management target process in the Board of Management target process section.
    Percentage of variable remuneration dependent on sustainability-related targets and (or) impacts Remuneration Report Compliance with sustainability requirements is factored into the individual contribution factor, which can increase or decrease the achievement of targets for the annual bonus and long-term compensation by 20 %. Therefore, the contribution factor has a total range of up to 40 %. Approximately one-third of the individual contribution factor is tied to sustainability goals. Since the variable component constitutes 70 % of the target compensation, the individual contribution factor can affect the total compensation by a maximum of 14 % positively or negatively. The overall range is 28 %. This applies to the entire variable compensation, including the annual bonus and long-term variable compensation.
    Description of level in undertaking at which terms of incentive schemes are approved and updated Remuneration Report – Determination of the remuneration system -

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation concernant les politiques de rémunération et les systèmes d'incitation liés aux objectifs de durabilité pour les membres des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. Il détaille les caractéristiques des systèmes d'incitation, les cibles spécifiques liées à la durabilité, et la manière dont ces cibles sont intégrées dans les politiques de rémunération. Les annotations expliquent que les objectifs de durabilité sont pris en compte dans les facteurs de contribution individuels, influençant la rémunération variable. Environ un tiers de ces facteurs est lié aux objectifs de durabilité, avec un impact maximal de 14 % sur la rémunération totale. Certaines sections restent non détaillées.

  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau détaille les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité, ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les exigences "matérielles" incluent : 1. **ESRS 2 GOV-1** : Diversité de genre au sein du conseil (paragraphe 21 (d)) et pourcentage de membres indépendants du conseil (paragraphe 21 (e)), liés au rôle des organes administratifs, de gestion et de supervision. 2. **ESRS 2 GOV-4** : Déclaration sur la diligence raisonnable (paragraphe 30). 3. **ESRS E1-1** : Plan de transition vers la neutralité climatique d'ici 2050 (paragraphe 14) et exclusion des benchmarks alignés sur Paris (paragraphe 16 (g)), liés à la stratégie climatique et à la transition vers le net zéro. 4. **ESRS E1-4** : Objectifs de réduction des émissions de GES (paragraphe 34), couvrant les portefeuilles d'assurance, d'investissement et les opérations propres d'Allianz. 5. **ESRS E1-5** et **ESRS E1-6** : Consommation énergétique et mix énergétique (paragraphe 37), émissions totales de GES (paragraphe 44), et intensité des émissions de GES (paragraphes 53 à 55), liés aux métriques climatiques du groupe Allianz. Les exigences "non matérielles" ou "non pertinentes" concernent les activités liées aux combustibles fossiles, à la production chimique, aux armes controversées, au tabac (paragraphe 40 (d)), ainsi que les crédits carbone (paragraphe 56). and

    Disclosure requirement and related datapoint Materiality Sub-section/sub-sub-section

    ESRS 2 GOV-4 Statement on due diligence paragraph 30 Material Statement on due diligence
    ESRS 2 SBM-1 Involvement in activities related to fossil fuel activities paragraph 40 (d) Not material Not applicable, since not material

    ESRS 2 SBM-1 Involvement in activities related to cultivation and production of tobacco paragraph 40 (d) iv Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E1-1 Transition plan to reach climate neutrality by 2050 paragraph 14 Material Climate change strategy and net-zero transition
    ESRS E1-1 Undertakings excluded from Paris-aligned Benchmarks paragraph 16 (g) Material Climate change strategy and net-zero transition
    ESRS E1-4 GHG emission reduction targets paragraph 34 Material Targets related to climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio, Targets related to climate change mitigation for our investment portfolio and Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations
    ESRS E1-5 Energy consumption from fossil sources disaggregated by sources (only high climate impact sectors) paragraph 38 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E1-5 Energy consumption and mix paragraph 37 Material Climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group
    ESRS E1-5 Energy intensity associated with activities in high climate impact sectors paragraphs 40 to 43 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E1-6 Gross Scope 1, 2, and 3 Total GHG emissions paragraph 44 Material Climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group
    ESRS E1-6 Gross GHG emissions intensity, paragraphs 53 to 55 Material Climate-related metrics for the Allianz Group
    ESRS E1-7 GHG removals and carbon credits, paragraph 56 Not relevant Not applicable, since not relevant

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité, ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les éléments jugés "matériels" concernent principalement la diversité de genre au sein du conseil, l'indépendance des membres du conseil, la diligence raisonnable, les plans de transition vers la neutralité climatique, les objectifs de réduction des émissions de GES, et les métriques liées au climat pour le groupe Allianz. Les éléments "non matériels" ou "non pertinents" incluent les activités liées aux combustibles fossiles, à la production chimique, aux armes controversées, au tabac, et aux crédits carbone.

Les objectifs de réduction des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) d'Allianz sont alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C conformément à l'Accord de Paris. Dans les documents fournis, Allianz mentionne plusieurs fois son engagement à suivre des trajectoires de décarbonation alignées sur un réchauffement de 1,5°C, en utilisant des scénarios climatiques crédibles tels que ceux du rapport d'évaluation de l'IPCC et du modèle climatique One Earth.

Allianz a fixé des objectifs intermédiaires de réduction des émissions pour 2030 et utilise des trajectoires de décarbonation sectorielles pour divers secteurs, ce qui est en ligne avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris. Cependant, il n'est pas explicitement mentionné si Allianz suit les objectifs de l'initiative Science Based Targets (SBTi), mais l'entreprise semble s'aligner sur des pratiques similaires en se basant sur des scénarios scientifiques et des protocoles tels que le NZAOA Target-Setting Protocol.

En résumé, Allianz a pris des mesures pour s'assurer que ses objectifs de réduction des émissions sont compatibles avec une trajectoire de 1,5°C, bien qu'il n'y ait pas de mention explicite des objectifs SBTi dans les documents fournis.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • In line with our net-zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science-backed climate scenarios - such as those provided by the IPCC's 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios used include the International Energy Agency (IEA)'s Net-Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5 ℃ with only a limited or no overshoot of this temperature during this century. While the individual scenarios differ in their assumptions and narratives (including global future economic and public and private policy developments), they agree on a necessary emission reduction range for CO2 emissions of 36% to 69% from 2020 to 2030, with a median reduction of 48%. For GHG emissions, the range is 34% to 60%, with a median of 43%. All our existing sub-portfolio targets for our operations, proprietary investments, and Property-Casualty
  • ### Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net-Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year-end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50%, 65%, and 70% respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year-end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year-end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65% across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.
  • ### Targets related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio We deem the framework of the NZAOA Target-Setting Protocol (TSP) as best practice for setting GHG emission reduction targets. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC's climate scenarios1, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5℃ with no or limited overshoot during the century. The TSP was aligned with relevant stakeholders, including academia, and vetted in a public consultation. Thus, we generally follow its recommendations for our intermediate decarbonization targets. It should be noted that while the NZAOA TSP defines targets for engagements, sectors, and low- carbon solutions, we display these as actions in line with regulatory definitions in ESRS E1. When setting these targets, we considered potential future developments in large industries, especially the E.U. and the U.S., based on the latest climate laws and regulations.
  • # --- Page 40 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement achieve the 2030 target, which is supported by ongoing or planned actions. The breakdown of our GHG emissions reduction target by Scopes is as follows. For Scope 1, Allianz Own Operations plans to reduce emissions per employee by 66% by 2030, and for Scope 2, we plan to reduce emissions per employee by 89% by 2030 compared to a 2019 baseline. Both targets are in line with the science-based-aligned minimum linear reduction rate for Scope 1 and 2 to limit global warming to 1.5℃. For Scope 3, our target is to reduce emissions per employee by 42% by 2030, compared to a 2019 baseline. The table below shows how each action contributes to the targets for the different scopes.
  • While the decision to define an intensity target allows us to reflect the expected growth of our portfolio by 2030 in a dynamic way, we have ensured that our targeted reduction is still within the scenario range to limit global warming to 1.5℃. Specifically, we have aimed to set an emission reduction target in the ranges of the IPCC net-zero scenarios by 2030. We also considered a growth in premium to simulate business growth while considering the resulting increase in insurance-associated emissions. In addition to factoring in expected portfolio growth, our target definition was also informed by the anticipated real economy decarbonization, which we modeled using authoritative scenarios such as the STEPS scenario of the IEA and publicly available and verified company commitments. The targets were developed with the support of dedicated teams at AGCS and finally approved by the Group Sustainability Board.
  • Our target setting is aligned with pathways to limit global warming to 1.5℃ and was informed by market decarbonization, modeled using scenarios from an external data partner. The pathways simulated developments in the motor market and ranged from an "as is" status to a "net-zero" status by 2050. We took a conservative view on potential emission reductions from continued real-world changes and focused on developing decarbonization levers to bridge the gap between market changes and the total required emission reduction to align with our 2030 targets. When setting the targets, we considered future developments such as: decarbonization of the real economy and implementation of government decarbonization commitments, as well as changes in customer behavior such as driving less or the increased use of public transport/e-mobility. When considering potential initiatives, we took into account future projections in the nine in-scope markets, including energy usage, vehicle usage, and vehicle
  • ### END TABLE 1_Coverage as per Transition Pathway Initiative universe and metrics. 2_As outlined in the inaugural transition plan, we have set a sector target for automobiles. However, this target covers Scope 3 (cat 11) emissions only and does therefore not directly contribute to our emission reduction target. Hence, we do not pursue this target further. 3_We have updated our 2030 target values to the 2028 Transition Pathway Initiative benchmark values, which are appropriate as they reflect the one year time lag in our emission data. Also, these targets build on the recommendations of the NZAOA TSP. They further incorporate potential and expected public and private policy developments which would close the gap towards the net-zero scenario. The targets trigger three types of actions: sector engagements, restrictions, and moving from climate laggards to climate leaders within the respective sectors.
  • We aim to finance the transition of companies in the hard-to- abate cement and steel sector that are aligned with a 1.5℃ path and have well-defined decarbonization strategies. We therefore created a separate emission bucket for new investments in those companies2 on our "steel and cement climate list," meaning that the financed emissions of these new investments are shown separately in the emissions table under "No target yet" and are not part of the 2030 corporate sub-portfolio emission target. Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE

Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

Les objectifs de réduction d'émissions fixés par l'entreprise sont alignés avec une trajectoire de réchauffement à 1,5°C, conformément aux Accords de Paris. Les informations fournies dans les différents contextes indiquent que les cibles de réduction d'émissions de CO2 et de GES sont en ligne avec les scénarios climatiques basés sur la science, tels que ceux du rapport d'évaluation de l'IPCC et le modèle climatique One Earth, qui limitent le réchauffement global à 1,5°C avec un dépassement limité ou nul de cette température au cours du siècle.

En ce qui concerne les objectifs spécifiques, l'entreprise a défini des cibles de réduction des émissions de GHG d'ici 2025, 2029, et 2030, avec des réductions prévues de 50%, 65%, et 70% respectivement, en utilisant 2019 comme année de référence. Ces objectifs prennent en compte les Scopes 1, 2, et certains éléments du Scope 3, assurant ainsi une diminution des émissions par employé.

Il est mentionné que les objectifs suivent le protocole de fixation des cibles de la NZAOA, considéré comme une bonne pratique pour établir des objectifs de réduction des émissions de GHG. Les trajectoires de décarbonation sont soutenues par des scénarios crédibles et alignées avec les développements réglementaires récents, surtout dans l'UE et aux États-Unis.

Cependant, il n'est pas explicitement mentionné si ces objectifs sont conformes aux objectifs SBTi (Science Based Targets initiative), bien que l'approche semble être globalement alignée avec les recommandations de l'Accord de Paris.

Sources Azure :
  • to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Our targets are defined considering market -based scope 2 emis sions as well as SAF. Targets related to climate change mitigation for Allianz Own Operations Overarching GHG reduction target(s) In our Inaugural Net -Zero Transition Plan (INZTP), published in September 2023, we set GHG emission intensity reduction targets for year -end 2025, 2029, and 2030 of 50 %, 65 %, and 70 % respectively, using 2019 as the baseline. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP. to be included in the next GHG Protocol Scope 3 Standard revision. Since we have already exceeded the interim year -end 2025 target in past years, and to ensure consistency across the Allianz Group business functions, we are now focusing on the 2030 target (i.e. year -end 2029). The 2030 target aims to reduce GHG emissions per employee by 65 % across Scope 1, Scope 2, and selected Scope 3 emissions (see section GHG emissions of Allianz Own Operations ). The decarbonization and removal targets for Allianz Own Operations remain as stated in the INZTP.

Our engagement approach is further outlined in the subsequent sections below, and in the section Sustainability strategy and governance . Similarly, for our supply chain, we also expect 100 % of global framework vendors (i.e., vendors providing products and services under global master agreements with Allianz SE) to have made a public commitment to net-zero GHG emissions in line with a 1.5 °C path by 2025.   • For motor retail insurance, our target is to reduce the absolute carbon emissions within our in- scope portfolios by 30 % by 2030 compared to our 2022 baseline. The target covers nine key European markets, namely: Austria, Belgium, France, Italy, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland, and the U.K. For 2024, the in -scope portfolios within these markets represented 53 % of the motor retail premiums in the same year. These markets were chosen to focus on the most relevant and largest motor markets for Al lianz where adequate and reliable data was available. The in -scope portfolios were classified in line with the PCAF standard for personal motor. The target only covers CO 2 emissions, in line with the data which is currently available. Our target setting is aligned with pathways to limit global warming to 1.5 °C and was informed by market decarbonization, modeled using scenarios from an external data partner.   • 1.5 °C pathways We consider our impact on climate change to result from the GHG emissions generated from our business (Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions). For Scope 3, category 15, our reporting boundaries are in line with GHG Protocol so that currently, assets under management owned by third parties and unit -linked funds are not part of the emissions reporting boundaries at Allianz Group . In line with our net -zero commitment, we have set intermediate targets for 2030, which are further underpinned by actions toward achieving our targets. Our emission targets are aligned with credible, science- backed climate scenarios – such as those provide d by the IPCC’s 6th Assessment Report. Further scenarios used include the International Energy Agency (IEA)’s Net -Zero by 2050 and the One Earth Climate Model; these limit global warming in 2100 to 1.5 °C with only a limited or no overshoot of this tempera ture during this century. 1.5 °C pathways We consider our impact on climate change to result from the GHG emissions generated from our business (Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions).   • changes require widespread support. Our net -zero commitment and ability to implement decarbonization actions depend significantly on governments fulfilling the ambitious goals of the Paris Agreement through swi ft, stable, and reliable public policies, action plans, and regulations. This includes the need for adequate frameworks and market incentives to enable the transition of the global economy along 1.5 °C pathways. The private sector needs to play an important role in supporting actions toward this transition. In pursuit of this, we actively engage with policymakers and regulators to support sustainable financing and achieve the goals outlined in the Pari s Agreement. We are advocating for effective global climate policy which should achieve the following: − Embedding “net -zero by 2050” in short - and long -term governmental climate targets, climate strategies, and emissions changes require widespread support. The TSP was developed with a strong reference to IPCC’s climate scenarios1, limiting temperature increase by the end of the century to 1.5 °C with no or limited overshoot during the century .   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
E1-6

Quels sont les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise ?

Pour répondre à cette question, nous souhaitons avoir la liste ou les noms des actions menées, accompagnées d'une description simple. Si possible, afficher les objectifs de réduction pour chacune des actions, avec l'année cible et l'année de référence.

1. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction.
2. Métrique.
3. Périmètre des émissions (Scope 1, 2 ou 3).
4. Année de référence.
5. Objectif de réduction.
6. Année cible. Des informations moins primordiales, mais souhaitables pourraient être :

- La méthodologie utilisée ou l'initiative correspondante.
- Les objectifs intermédiaires (2030, 2035, 2040, 2045).

Je ne dispose pas d'informations détaillées sur un plan de transition spécifique d'une entreprise précise à partir des contextes fournis. Cependant, je peux vous donner un aperçu général des leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans plusieurs contextes :

  1. Énergie Renouvelable

    • Nom de l'action : Utilisation d'électricité renouvelable
    • Métrique : ktCO2e
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 2 et Scope 3
    • Année de référence et cible : 2024 et 2029
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de (2.9) à 1.1 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales

  2. Efficacité Énergétique

    • Nom de l'action : Réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage
    • Métrique : ktCO2e
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et Scope 3
    • Année de référence et cible : 2024 et 2029
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de 3.0 à 1.0 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales

  3. Mobilité Verte

    • Nom de l'action : Green fleet
    • Métrique : ktCO2e
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et Scope 2
    • Année de référence et cible : 2024 et 2029
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de (5.2) à 0.8 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales

  4. Autres Initiatives

    • Nom de l'action : Optimisation des voyages aériens
    • Métrique : ktCO2e
    • Périmètre des émissions : Scope 1 et Scope 2
    • Année de référence et cible : 2024 et 2029
    • Objectif de réduction : Réduction de (3.1) à 0.9 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales

Les informations ci-dessus représentent des leviers et actions de décarbonation généraux tels que détaillés dans les contextes fournis. Les objectifs de réduction spécifiques, les années cibles et les méthodes utilisées peuvent varier d'une entreprise à l'autre.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour les périodes 1.1.2024-31.12.2024 et 1.1.2025-31.12.2029, ainsi que les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les leviers incluent : "Start of period versus baseline", "Renewable energy", "Energy efficiency", "Green mobility" et "Other". - Les actions spécifiques comprennent : "Renewable energy", "Renewable electricity", "Reduction of heating energy consumption", "Reduction of electricity consumption", "Green fleet", "Air travel optimization¹", et diverses autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 incluent une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 varient selon les leviers et les portées : Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Par exemple, pour "Renewable electricity", les changements attendus sont de (2.9) à 1.1 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, 1.1 ktCO2e pour Scope 2, et de (1.9) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 3. - Pour "Reduction of heating energy consumption", les changements attendus sont de 3.0 à 1.0 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales, et de (1.0) à 1.0 ktCO2e pour Scope 1 et Scope 3. - Les leviers "Green mobility" et "Air travel optimization¹" montrent également des réductions significatives, avec des variations selon les portées. - Les initiatives regroupées sous "Other" incluent des ajustements liés à la consommation d'électricité des centres de données, des véhicules de location, du papier, et du cloud, avec des réductions attendues de (2.1) à 1.9 ktCO2e pour les émissions totales. - À la fin de la période, une réduction totale de 65.0 ktCO2e est attendue par rapport au début de la période, avec des impacts spécifiques sur Scope 1 (5.2 ktCO2e), Scope 2 (40.1 ktCO2e), et Scope 3 (19.6 ktCO2e). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonation, les actions associées et les changements réalisés ou attendus dans les émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) pour différentes périodes et portées (Scope 1, Scope 2, Scope 3). - Les leviers incluent l'énergie renouvelable, l'efficacité énergétique, la mobilité verte et d'autres initiatives. - Les changements réalisés dans les émissions de GES pour la période 2024 sont détaillés, avec une réduction totale de 61.5 ktCO2e par rapport au début de la période. - Les changements attendus pour la période 2025-2029 sont estimés pour chaque levier, avec des variations dans les portées Scope 1, Scope 2 et Scope 3. - Les actions spécifiques incluent l'utilisation d'électricité renouvelable, la réduction de la consommation d'énergie pour le chauffage et l'électricité, l'optimisation des flottes et des voyages aériens, ainsi que des ajustements liés aux centres de données et autres activités.

Les changements supplémentaires dans le portefeuille ont entraîné une réduction de (3.8) en 2024 et sont estimés entre 4.1 et (2.1) pour 2025-2029. and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les leviers de décarbonisation, les actions associées, les réductions des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GHG) réalisées pour la période 2024, ainsi que les réductions attendues pour la période 2025-2029. Les réductions réalisées en 2024 totalisent 8,1 unités, tandis que les réductions attendues pour 2025-2029 s'élèvent à 44 unités. Certaines actions, comme l'engagement des locataires, ne sont pas quantifiables. Les réductions attendues varient selon les actions, avec des plages spécifiques indiquées pour chaque catégorie.

  • the decarbonization levers for our motor retail portfolio. Each lever is into specific actions, highlighting their respective broken down contributions to reducing CO2 emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a baseline target value, covering the period from the beginning to the end of 2024. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to the end of 2029, represented in ranges to account for potential variability. The lower ranges in the table reflect the maximum decarbonization effort and the upper ranges reflect the minimum decarbonization effort. the decarbonization levers for our motor retail portfolio. Each lever is into specific actions, highlighting their respective broken down contributions to reducing CO2 emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a baseline target value, covering the period from the beginning to the end of 2024. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to the end of 2029, represented in ranges to account for potential variability. The lower ranges in the table reflect the maximum decarbonization effort and the upper ranges reflect the minimum decarbonization effort.
  • Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Some emission sources are not covered by an action or target and thus a decarbonization lever, such as rental cars, rail travel, private car use for business purposes, and others. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for own operations. The travel target of a GHG emission reduction of 40 % per employee by year-end 2025 against a 2019 baseline as disclosed in the Allianz Annual Report 2023 was redefined into two targets: Green Fleet and Business Travel (excl. fleet). This reflects Allianz’s ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet). Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Some emission sources are not covered by an action or target and thus a decarbonization lever, such as rental cars, rail travel, private car use for business purposes, and others. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for own operations. The travel target of a GHG emission reduction of 40 % per employee by year-end 2025 against a 2019 baseline as disclosed in the Allianz Annual Report 2023 was redefined into two targets: Green Fleet and Business Travel (excl. fleet). This reflects Allianz’s ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet).
  • The main decarbonization levers in our own operations are renewable electricity, energy efficiency, and green mobility, with key actions comprising renewable electricity procurement, reduction of electricity and heat consumption, green fleet, and air travel decarbonization. The Allianz Group is not dependent on the allocation of resources because our specialized in-house teams drive the progress of our actions and the implementation of the transition plan, and these teams are implicitly incorporated into the financial plan. Experts must be deployed at a corporate level to ensure actions follow Allianz’s sustainability strategy, and at an operating entity level to ensure technical implementation. Further, Allianz’s ability to implement actions depends on data availability and collection, both in terms of its own operations and business activities. Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio The main decarbonization levers in our own operations are renewable electricity, energy efficiency, and green mobility, with key actions comprising renewable electricity procurement, reduction of electricity and heat consumption, green fleet, and air travel decarbonization. The Allianz Group is not dependent on the allocation of resources because our specialized in-house teams drive the progress of our actions and the implementation of the transition plan, and these teams are implicitly incorporated into the financial plan. Experts must be deployed at a corporate level to ensure actions follow Allianz’s sustainability strategy, and at an operating entity level to ensure technical implementation. Further, Allianz’s ability to implement actions depends on data availability and collection, both in terms of its own operations and business activities. Climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio

Les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise Allianz sont divers et s'appliquent à différents secteurs d'activités. Voici un résumé des actions menées :

  1. Insured Customer Decarbonization

    • Métrique: Intensité des émissions du client (émissions absolues de GES divisées par le revenu du client).
    • Périmètre des émissions: Scope 3, car cela dépend des changements au sein des entreprises clientes.
    • Objectif de réduction: Non spécifié de manière chiffrée pour chaque client, car cela dépend des actions propres du client.

  2. Portfolio Steering

    • Métrique: Composition du portefeuille.
    • Périmètre des émissions: Scope 3, puisqu’il s’agit des investissements ou de l’assurance d’entreprises tierces.
    • Objectif de réduction: Modifications continues pour alignement avec les objectifs climatiques.

  3. Investee Company Decarbonization

    • Métrique: Réduction des émissions de GES des entreprises dans lesquelles Allianz investit.
    • Périmètre des émissions: Scope 3.
    • Objectif de réduction: Alignement avec le scénario IEA Net-Zero Emissions by 2050.

  4. Engagements on Net Zero Transition

    • Métrique: Engagement avec les entreprises à haute émission pour réduire les risques.
    • Périmètre des émissions: Scope 3.
    • Objectif de réduction: Non quantifiable directement mais vise à influencer positivement les pratiques des entreprises.

  5. Low Carbon Solution Investments

    • Métrique: Investissements dans des solutions bas carbone.
    • Périmètre des émissions: Scope 3.
    • Objectif de réduction: Investir 20 milliards d'euros dans des solutions bas carbone.

  6. Restrictions and Portfolio Changes

    • Métrique: Modification des investissements pour réduire l’exposition aux entreprises à fortes émissions.
    • Périmètre des émissions: Scope 3.
    • Objectif de réduction: Réductions attendues de 50.7% à 61.3% par rapport à la ligne de base de 2019 d'ici 2029.

Ces actions sont soutenues par des engagements à long terme pour réduire les émissions de GES et aligner les pratiques d'investissement avec les objectifs climatiques mondiaux. Les objectifs intermédiaires et les méthodologies spécifiques ne sont pas détaillés dans les contextes fournis.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • The table below presents an in-depth analysis of the decarbonization levers for our motor retail portfolio. Each lever is broken down into specific actions, highlighting their respective contributions to reducing CO2 emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a baseline target value, covering the period from the beginning to the end of 2024. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to the end of 2029, represented in ranges to account for potential variability. The lower ranges in the table reflect the maximum decarbonization effort and the upper ranges reflect the minimum decarbonization effort.
  • ### Further portfolio changes Finally, the remaining reduction in emissions intensity will be reached by changing the portfolio mix. Following the reduction effect from other key actions of the portfolio steering lever, a change in the portfolio mix will be applied to the overall emission intensity of the target portfolio. The table below presents an in-depth analysis of the decarbonization levers employed for the portfolio in scope of our commercial target.
  • ### Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for Allianz own operations There are three main decarbonization levers for our own operations: renewable energy, energy efficiency, and green mobility. Some emission sources are not covered by an action or target and thus a decarbonization lever, such as rental cars, rail travel, private car use for business purposes, and others. Each action is covered by a separate target, although some targets cover multiple actions at once. In addition, all actions are covered by the overall GHG emission reduction target for own operations. The travel target of a GHG emission reduction of 40% per employee by year-end 2025 against a 2019 baseline as disclosed in the Allianz Annual Report 2023 was redefined into two targets: Green Fleet and Business Travel (excl. fleet). This reflects Allianz's ambition to transition to a green fleet while separately addressing GHG emissions from business travel (excl. fleet).
  • ### Corporates For our corporate portfolio, we have set the following four targets on actions to pull the two decarbonization levers. These actions relate partially to addressing risks and opportunities, in addition to our inside-out impact: - Engage high-emitting companies in our portfolio to increase our positive impact and reduce risks; - Invest € 20 bn in low-carbon solutions to increase our positive impact and seize opportunities; - Align specific high-emitting sectors (oil and gas, utilities (coal), and steel1) with IEA Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario to reduce negative impact and risks in our portfolio; - Restrict fossil fuel-related business models in a targeted manner to reduce our risk and negative impact.
  • ### Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio For both commercial and motor retail insurance, we have two decarbonization levers: insured customer decarbonization and portfolio steering.
  • ### Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for our proprietary investment portfolio For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for reducing GHG emissions: either the assets (i.e., our portfolio companies or our real estate investments) reduce their GHG emissions (investee company decarbonization), or we change the composition of our portfolio over time (portfolio steering). To this end, we have different actions in place to support emission reductions.
  • Our future emissions reduction strategy relies to a significant extent on the decarbonization of energy grids as well as our of tenant- controlled emissions. This lever as well as the actions under our direct control generally point in the right direction and we are on track to achieve our long-term goals, in line with our CRREM target. We are implementing measures, such as energy efficiency upgrades, renewable energy adoption, tenant engagement programs, and pursuing green building certifications.

Each lever is broken down into specific actions, highlighting their respective contributions to reducing GHG emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a 2019 baseline. Additionally, it projects future developments and anticipated emission reductions through to 2030, represented in ranges to account for potential variability.

Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE

Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Ambos son materiales y se relacionan con las políticas de ESRS y el modelo de negocio estratégico para los trabajadores en la cadena de valor. 2. **ESRS S2-4** trata temas de derechos humanos e incidentes en la cadena de valor (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos para remediar impactos negativos. 3. **ESRS S3-1** incluye compromisos de políticas de derechos humanos (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs, OIT u OCDE (párrafo 17), ambos materiales y vinculados al modelo de negocio estratégico para comunidades afectadas. 4. **ESRS S3-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 36), considerado material, con enfoque en objetivos, acciones, canales para plantear preocupaciones y procesos de interacción con comunidades afectadas. 5. **ESRS S4-1** sobre políticas relacionadas con consumidores y usuarios finales (párrafo 16) y el incumplimiento de principios de UNGPs y OCDE (párrafo 17) no son materiales. 6. **ESRS S4-4** aborda temas e incidentes de derechos humanos (párrafo 35), considerado material, con enfoque en acciones. 7. **ESRS G1-1** sobre la Convención de las Naciones Unidas contra la Corrupción (párrafo 10 (b)) y la protección de denunciantes (párrafo 10 (d)) no son relevantes, ya que las políticas ya están implementadas. 8. **ESRS G1-4** sobre multas por violación de leyes anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (a)) y estándares anticorrupción y antirrobo (párrafo 24 (b)) son materiales, con enfoque en incidentes confirmados de corrupción o soborno. 9. Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

Je ne peux pas fournir une réponse complète à votre question sur les leviers de décarbonation identifiés dans le plan de transition de l'entreprise car les informations détaillées demandées ne sont pas disponibles dans les documents fournis. Voici cependant un résumé des leviers de décarbonation mentionnés dans les contextes :

  1. Nom de l'action ou du projet de réduction:

    • Énergie renouvelable
    • Efficacité énergétique
    • Mobilité verte
    • Décarbonisation des clients assurés
    • Pilotage de portefeuille

  2. Métrique:

    • Réduction des émissions de CO2 en pourcentage par rapport à une valeur de référence

  3. Périmètre des émissions:

    • Non spécifié dans les contextes

  4. Année de référence:

    • 2019 pour certaines actions de réduction des émissions

  5. Objectif de réduction:

    • Par exemple, une réduction de 40% des émissions de GES par employé d'ici fin 2025 par rapport à 2019 pour certaines actions

  6. Année cible:

    • 2025 pour certaines actions, 2030 pour d'autres

Malheureusement, je n'ai pas d'informations sur la méthodologie utilisée, les initiatives correspondantes ou les objectifs intermédiaires spécifiques à chaque projet de réduction.

  • (EU) 2020/1818 and is thus not excluded from E.U. Paris -aligned benchmarks. In the subsequent sections, we outline the integration of the transition plan into our business strategy and how we assess and address the impacts, risks, and opportunities of climate change mitigation . Introduction to Allianz Group decarbonization levers For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for decarbonization to reduce GHG emissions: either our portfolio companies – i.e., the customers and activities we insure or the companies we invest in – reduce their GHG emissions, or we change the composition of our portfolio over time through portfolio steering. The former relies directly on GHG emission reductions in the real economy, which are not under our control. The latter can occur naturally as part of typical insurance and investment business cycles in different lines of business, sectors, and individual c ustomers, and is generally more under our control. (EU) 2020/1818 and is thus not excluded from E.U. Paris -aligned benchmarks. In the subsequent sections, we outline the integration of the transition plan into our business strategy and how we assess and address the impacts, risks, and opportunities of climate change mitigation . Introduction to Allianz Group decarbonization levers For our portfolio targets, there are generally two levers for decarbonization to reduce GHG emissions: either our portfolio companies – i.e., the customers and activities we insure or the companies we invest in – reduce their GHG emissions, or we change the composition of our portfolio over time through portfolio steering. The former relies directly on GHG emission reductions in the real economy, which are not under our control. The latter can occur naturally as part of typical insurance and investment business cycles in different lines of business, sectors, and individual c ustomers, and is generally more under our control.
  • opportunities. Additionally, it builds resilience by preparing the company for stricter future regulations and market demands for lower emissions, ensuring adaptability in a transitioning economy . Decarbonization levers and actions related to climate change mitigation for our insurance portfolio For both commercial and motor retail insurance, we have two decarbonization levers: insured customer decarbonization and portfolio steering. Commercial insurance For commercial insurance, there are four key actions that contribute to the decarbonization levers. The customer decarbonization action refers to the change in a customer’s own emission intensity. The customer’s emission intensity is the absolute GHG emissions of the customer (tons of CO 2e) divided by their revenue ( €). Customer decarbonization relies entirely on changes occurring within the customer’s business, independent of any underwriting decision or action taken by Allianz . The contribution of opportunities. Additionally, it builds resilience by preparing the company for stricter future regulations and market demands for lower emissions, ensuring adaptability in a transitioning economy . The customer’s emission intensity is the absolute GHG emissions of the customer (tons of CO 2e) divided by their revenue ( €).   • before progressing to the Sustainability Board and finally the Board of Management for approval. To define the decarbonization levers and actions for the motor retail portfolio, Allianz considered four scenarios provided by an external data partner. The scenarios projected market developments, and ranged from an “as is” scenario to a “net -zero” scenario up to 2050. Allianz decided to adopt the second -most conservative, which included emission reductions by continued real -world changes, including government pledges and commitments, to develop its decarbonization levers. Therefore, our actions have been developed to close the gap to net -zero. The table below presents an in -depth analysis of the decarbonization levers for our motor retail portfolio. Each lever is broken down into specific actions, highlighting their respective contributions to reducing CO 2 emissions. The table tracks the percentage decrease in emissions compared to a baseline target before progressing to the Sustainability Board and finally the Board of Management for approval. All figures are presented as percentages.   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • NatCat scenarios and global hazard maps. However, effecti ve adaptation to climate change not only requires adequate pricing of risks, but also individual measures by customers. We have therefore started considering preventative actions taken by the customer in our products and pricing models. Living up to our ro le as a climate risk manager, we are also integrating advisory services into our customer communication and we provide relevant information to customers, for example, on how to build stronger resilience to climate- related events. In addition, we are committed to offering comprehensive insurance products for low -carbon technologies – such as battery electric vehicles (BEV) and the related ecosystem – as well as for renewable energy technologies, to support the transition of our cust omers toward more environment -friendly solutions. For instance, Allianz entities offer BEV insurance products, which meet the specific NatCat scenarios and global hazard maps. In addition, we are committed to offering comprehensive insurance products for low -carbon technologies – such as battery electric vehicles (BEV) and the related ecosystem – as well as for renewable energy technologies, to support the transition of our cust omers toward more environment -friendly solutions. For instance, Allianz entities offer BEV insurance products, which meet the specific
  • investments in employees, external expertise, third party databases, IT systems and more. Together with an increase in operat ional compl exity, such new regulations may drive an increase in compliance or process failures and operational losses. Opportunities Insurance Opportunities are considered material for our insurance portfolio (Property -Casualty retail and commercial ) in that we are supporting our customers in their low -carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our Sustainable Solutions and low -carbon solutions. Proprietary investments Opportunities are considered material for our proprietary investments in that we are supporting our investees in their low -carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our low -carbon solutions. G1-41

Quelle est la valeur monétaire des contributions politiques, financières et en nature apportées directement et indirectement par l'entreprise ? Distinguer le montant total des contributions financières directes, des contributions financières indirectes et des contributions en nature.

Contexte: Pour cette question, nous analysons les activités et politiques de lobbying de l'entreprise. On entend par « contribution politique », l'aide financière ou en nature apportée directement aux partis politiques, à leurs représentants élus ou aux personnes qui briguent une fonction politique. Les contributions financières incluent les dons, les prêts, les parrainages, les avances pour services, ou l'achat de billets pour des événements de collecte de fonds et d'autres pratiques similaires.
Les contributions en nature incluent la publication, l'utilisation d'installations, la conception et l'impression, le don de matériel, l'adhésion à un conseil d'administration, l'emploi ou le travail de consultance pour des responsables politiques élus ou des candidats à un mandat.
Par « contribution politique indirecte », on entend les contributions politiques apportées par l'intermédiaire d'une organisation (de lobbying ou caritative par exemple) ou l'aide apportée à une organisation, par exemple un groupe de réflexion ou une organisation professionnelle proche de certains partis ou de certaines causes politiques, ou qui soutient ces partis/causes.

Consignes: Distinguer le montant total des contributions financières directes, des contributions financières indirectes et des contributions en nature.
Pour chaque type de contribution, indiquer si les données sont disponibles, ainsi que le pays ou la zone géographique et le bénéficiaire de la contribution.
Présenter les données sous forme de tableau, avec les années et les montants respectifs.
Veuillez noter que si ces valeurs ne sont pas affichées, cela peut être interprété comme un signe que l'entreprise ne verse pas de contributions politiques ou d'autres contributions financières liées à l'influence et aux pratiques de lobbying.

Je suis désolé, mais les informations disponibles ne fournissent pas de détails spécifiques pour distinguer les montants totaux des contributions financières directes, des contributions financières indirectes et des contributions en nature. Les données disponibles mentionnent uniquement une contribution globale de 458.8 (unité non précisée) pour l'année 2024, sans décomposer entre contributions directes, indirectes et en nature. Les données pour l'année 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (indiquées par "n.a."). Quant aux zones géographiques, la majorité des contributions politiques proviennent d'Europe (environ 80 %), avec le reste provenant de la région Asie-Pacifique et des Amériques. Cependant, il n'existe pas de détails supplémentaires sur le pays ou les bénéficiaires spécifiques pour chaque type de contribution.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Our quantitative disclosures on political contributions take financial as well as in-kind contributions into consideration. For our financial contributions, our disclosures include the monetary value of direct donations to any individual politician or individuals running for office, political parties, and directly affiliated organizations, as well as the monetary value of indirect financial political contributions made to any political party through an in-kind contributions, our disclosures include the use of facilities, design, and printing, as well as the Allianz SE Board members’ contributions, the provision of Allianz SE Board memberships to representatives of political parties, and the provision of non-monetary support to any political cause or entity through an intermediary. One example of an in-kind contribution of an Allianz SE Board member could be the monetary value of their working time spent holding a speech at a political panel discussion. Our quantitative disclosures on political contributions take financial as well as in-kind contributions into consideration. For our financial contributions, our disclosures include the monetary value of direct donations to any individual politician or individuals running for office, political parties, and directly affiliated organizations, as well as the monetary value of indirect financial political contributions made to any political party through an in-kind contributions, our disclosures include the use of facilities, design, and printing, as well as the Allianz SE Board members’ contributions, the provision of Allianz SE Board memberships to representatives of political parties, and the provision of non-monetary support to any political cause or entity through an intermediary. One example of an in-kind contribution of an Allianz SE Board member could be the monetary value of their working time spent holding a speech at a political panel discussion.

  • ### END TABLE 1_The majority of political contributions, around 80 %, originates from Europe, while the rest is from Asia Pacific and the Americas. Additionally, about two-thirds of the political contributions are financial, with the remaining one-third being in-kind contributions. According to our Group policy, in-kind contributions are measured based on market values whenever possible, mainly for real estate (e.g., providing office space) or donation of equipment. Further, Allianz SE board members’ in-kind contributions are measured based on business hours spent. To calculate the monetary value of the business hours spent, we use the following formula, according to the calculation method for the German Lobby Register: Share of hours spent by 147 G1 Business Conduct Allianz SE Board members in their total working hours* (base salary + annual bonus). Main lobbying activities Our lobbying activities in 2024 included the following main topics: ### END TABLE 1_The majority of political contributions, around 80 %, originates from Europe, while the rest is from Asia Pacific and the Americas. Additionally, about two-thirds of the political contributions are financial, with the remaining one-third being in-kind contributions. According to our Group policy, in-kind contributions are measured based on market values whenever possible, mainly for real estate (e.g., providing office space) or donation of equipment. Further, Allianz SE board members’ in-kind contributions are measured based on business hours spent. To calculate the monetary value of the business hours spent, we use the following formula, according to the calculation method for the German Lobby Register: Share of hours spent by 147 G1 Business Conduct Allianz SE Board members in their total working hours* (base salary + annual bonus). Les catégories incluent : 1. **Entreprises non financières** : - Turnover : 1.1% (8.4 milliards d'euros). - CAPEX : 1.5% (11.2 milliards d'euros). 2. **Entreprises financières** : - Turnover : 0.2% (1.2 milliard d'euros). - CAPEX : 0.2% (1.5 milliard d'euros). 3. **Investissements des entreprises d'assurance ou de réassurance** (hors contrats d'assurance-vie où le risque est supporté par les preneurs) : - Turnover : 1.2% (9.4 milliards d'euros). - CAPEX : 1.6% (12.4 milliards d'euros). 4. **Autres contreparties et actifs** : - Turnover : 0.8% (6.4 milliards d'euros). - CAPEX : 0.6% (4.4 milliards d'euros). Les ratios varient de 0.2% à 1.6%, et les montants monétaires vont de 1.2 à 12.4 milliards d'euros. and

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les proportions et les montants monétaires des expositions alignées sur la taxonomie pour différents types d'entreprises et d'investissements. Les données sont réparties en fonction du chiffre d'affaires (Turnover) et des dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX). Les ratios en pourcentage et les montants monétaires sont fournis pour les entreprises non financières, les entreprises financières, les investissements des entreprises d'assurance ou de réassurance, ainsi que pour les autres contreparties et actifs. Les ratios varient de 0.2% à 1.6%, tandis que les montants monétaires vont de 1.2 à 12.4 milliards d'euros.
