Les données pour CCM et CCA ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • Le tableau présente les objectifs de réduction des émissions de CO₂ d'Allianz pour ses propres opérations, ses investissements propriétaires et ses activités d'assurance, avec des valeurs de référence, des performances pour 2023 et 2024, ainsi que des écarts en pourcentage par rapport aux valeurs de référence. Les objectifs pour 2030 et les écarts prévus par rapport aux valeurs de référence sont également inclus. - **Allianz Own Operations** : Les émissions de CO₂ par employé (kg CO₂e/employee) ont diminué de 61,5 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2,366.7, avec un objectif de 828.3 kg CO₂e/employee en 2030, soit une réduction de 65 %. - **Proprietary Investments** : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi (t CO₂e/mn € invested) ont baissé de 46,5 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 108.1, avec un objectif de 54.0 en 2030, soit une réduction de 50 %. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ des entreprises cotées (mn t CO₂) ont diminué de 50,7 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 24.9, avec un objectif de 12.5 en 2030, soit une réduction de 50 %. - Les émissions de CO₂ par m² pour l'immobilier (kg CO₂e/m²) sont de 33.5 en 2023, avec un objectif d'environ 20 kg CO₂e/m² en 2030. - **Insurance** : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros de primes d'assurance commerciale (kt CO₂e/mn € Insurance Premium) ont baissé de 11,7 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 0.26, avec un objectif de 0.14 en 2030, soit une réduction de 45 %. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ pour le secteur automobile de détail (mn t CO₂) ont diminué de 6,8 % en 2023 par rapport à la valeur de référence de 2.10, avec un objectif de 1.47 en 2030, soit une réduction de 30 %. and

    Le tableau présente les progrès réalisés par Allianz en vue d'atteindre ses objectifs intermédiaires pour 2030 dans différents domaines, notamment ses propres opérations, ses investissements propriétaires et ses activités d'assurance. Les données incluent les valeurs de référence, les performances pour 2023 et 2024, ainsi que les écarts par rapport aux valeurs de référence en pourcentage. Les objectifs pour 2030 sont également indiqués, accompagnés des écarts prévus par rapport aux valeurs de référence.
    - Allianz Own Operations : Les émissions de CO₂ par employé ont diminué de 61,5 % par rapport à la valeur de référence, avec un objectif de réduction de 65 % d'ici 2030. - Proprietary Investments : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros investi ont baissé de 46,5 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 50 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ des entreprises cotées ont diminué de 50,7 %, avec un objectif similaire pour 2030. - Les émissions de CO₂ par m² pour l'immobilier sont en cours de suivi, avec un objectif d'environ 20 kg CO₂e/m² d'ici 2030. - Insurance : - Les émissions de CO₂ par million d'euros de primes d'assurance commerciale ont baissé de 11,7 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 45 % d'ici 2030. - Les émissions totales de CO₂ pour le secteur automobile de détail ont diminué de 6,8 %, avec un objectif de réduction de 30 % d'ici 2030.

Je ne dispose pas d'informations précises dans les documents fournis concernant des plans de dépenses spécifiques visant à augmenter les activités alignées à la taxonomie européenne, en détaillant les dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX) et les dépenses opérationnelles (OPEX) pour développer des activités durables. Les documents mentionnent des informations sur les activités économiques alignées avec la taxonomie, mais sans détails explicites sur des plans de dépenses futurs ou des stratégies spécifiques pour augmenter ces activités.

The rows are numbered from 1 to 8, with an additional row for totals. 1. **Row 1**: No data is provided for taxonomy-aligned activities under Section 4.26. 2. **Row 2**: Activities under Section 4.27 show an amount of 0.1 (monetary) and 0.5% for both CCM and CCA. 3. **Row 3**: Activities under Section 4.28 show an amount of 0.3 (monetary) and 1.6% for both CCM and CCA. 4. **Row 4**: Activities under Section 4.29 show no monetary amount for CCM and 0.1% proportion. 5. **Row 5**: Activities under Section 4.30 show no monetary amount for CCM and 0.1% proportion. 6. **Row 6**: Activities under Section 4.31 show an amount of 0.1 (monetary) and 0.6% for both CCM and CCA. 7. **Row 7**: Other taxonomy-aligned activities not listed in rows 1–6 show an amount of 16.6 (monetary) and 97.2% for CCM, and 0.1 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCA. 8. **Row 8**: The total amount and proportion of taxonomy-aligned activities are 17.1 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCM, and 17.0 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCA, with 0.1 (monetary) and 100.0% for CCA.   • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en términos de "Turnover" para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)", desglosadas en "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila 1, las actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía según la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 2, las actividades según la Sección 4.27 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 3. En la fila 3, las actividades según la Sección 4.28 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.4 (2.4% para CCM). 4. En la fila 4, las actividades según la Sección 4.29 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 5. En la fila 5, las actividades según la Sección 4.30 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.3 (0.3% para CCM). 6. En la fila 6, las actividades según la Sección 4.31 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 7. En la fila 8, el total de actividades alineadas con la taxonomía reporta un "Turnover" de 16.0 (100.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA).

La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en investigación, desarrollo, demostración y despliegue de instalaciones innovadoras de generación de electricidad que producen energía a partir de procesos nucleares con residuos mínimos del ciclo de combustible. **Estado:** NO. 2. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción y operación segura de nuevas instalaciones nucleares para producir electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno, y mejoras de seguridad utilizando las mejores tecnologías disponibles. 3. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la operación segura de instalaciones nucleares existentes que producen electricidad o calor de proceso, incluyendo calefacción distrital, procesos industriales como la producción de hidrógeno a partir de energía nuclear, y mejoras de seguridad. **Actividades relacionadas con el gas fósil:** 4. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción u operación de instalaciones de generación de electricidad que producen electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 5. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación combinada de calor/frío y electricidad utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. 6. La empresa realiza, financia o tiene exposiciones en la construcción, renovación y operación de instalaciones de generación de calor/frío utilizando combustibles gaseosos fósiles. **Estado:** NO. ### END TABLE
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre "Economic activities" y "CAPEX" en el contexto de actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía para el año 2023. Los datos están organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Row", "Economic activities", "CAPEX", "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila "1.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 2. En la fila "2.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.27 muestran un "Amount" de 0.0 y un porcentaje de 0.01% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 3. En la fila "3.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.28 tienen un "Amount" de 0.3 y un porcentaje de 0.04% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 4. Las filas "4.", "5." y "6." (Secciones 4.29, 4.30 y 4.31) no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 5. En la fila "7.", las actividades alineadas no incluidas en las filas anteriores tienen un "Amount" de 14.7 (1.98%), con 13.5 (1.82%) para CCM y 0.8 (0.11%) para CCA. 6. En la fila "8.", el "Total applicable KPI" es de 741.9, pero no hay datos disponibles ("n.a.") para CCM y CCA. Notas adicionales: "n.a." indica información no disponible, y no se asignaron cuotas de alineación a objetivos climáticos o actividades nucleares/gas debido a limitaciones de datos.

Je ne dispose pas d'informations spécifiques sur les plans de dépenses de l'entreprise visant à augmenter ses activités alignées à la Taxonomie européenne, notamment en ce qui concerne les détails des dépenses d'investissement (CAPEX) et des dépenses opérationnelles (OPEX) pour développer ses activités durables. Les documents fournis mentionnent des données sur les activités économiques alignées avec la taxonomie en termes de CAPEX pour les années 2023 et 2024, mais ne détaillent pas les plans de dépenses futurs ou les OPEX.

  • For 2024, Allianz has followed the disclosure guidance for insurer investment KPIs detailed in Annex IX/X of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/ 2178 ( Disclosure Delegated Act). As mentioned earlier, the main changes regarding the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1214 are the introduction of alignment KPIs (by turnover and CAPEX) and the separate tables required for nuclear/gas exposures. For Taxonomy reporting in 2024, there were some changes to how Allianz presents its numbers. The first change relates to the exclusion of investments which do not meet the IFRS definition of cash and cash equivalents (mainly cash deposits with a maturity between 3 months and one year or cash collaterals received on securities borrowing) but are co nsidered as cash equivalents by Allianz as these investments will never deploy a Taxonomy -aligned activity. After reassessing the E.U. Taxonomy Regulation, Allianz has determined that cash and cash equivalents For 2024, Allianz has followed the disclosure guidance for insurer investment KPIs detailed in Annex IX/X of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/ 2178 ( Disclosure Delegated Act). As mentioned earlier, the main changes regarding the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1214 are the introduction of alignment KPIs (by turnover and CAPEX) and the separate tables required for nuclear/gas exposures. For Taxonomy reporting in 2024, there were some changes to how Allianz presents its numbers. The first change relates to the exclusion of investments which do not meet the IFRS definition of cash and cash equivalents (mainly cash deposits with a maturity between 3 months and one year or cash collaterals received on securities borrowing) but are co nsidered as cash equivalents by Allianz as these investments will never deploy a Taxonomy -aligned activity. After reassessing the E.U. Taxonomy Regulation, Allianz has determined that cash and cash equivalents
  • the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime
  • Proprietary Investments Corporates1 t CO 2e/mn € invested 108.1 57.8 71.2 (46.5) 54.0 (50) Listed Corporates1 mn t CO 2e 24.9 12.3 14.0 (50.7) 12.5 (50) Real Estate2,3,4 kg CO 2e/m2 21.0 33.5 ca. 20 Insurance Commercial kt CO 2e/mn € Insurance Premium 0.26 0.23 0.22 (11.7) 0.14 (45) Motor Retail mn t CO 2 2.10 1.95 2.03 (6.8) 1.47 (30) 1_Both corporate targets exclude investments which qualify for the Allianz Steel and Cement Climate List. 2_ Including our portfolio managed by PIMCO Prime Real Estate (PPRE) and the direct portfolio of Allianz Switzerland. Therefore covers debt and equity investments and real estate assets held for investment purposes as per IFRS 9 categories. The target is s et in line with the CRREM pathways, therefore the basis for th e target setting is the pathways and not a baseline value.   • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
  • system, established in 2024, is built along the following components for applicable subsidiaries : − Dedicated GSCA Risk Experts, responsible for OHS are identified. − Health & Safety risk assessments are conducted at least annually, covering physical safety, workplace safety, and mental health. − Action plans are defined to address medium and high risks, incl. process tracking. There are processes in place to ensure monitoring of these components across the Allianz Group , which are outlined in more detail in the section Human rights in own workforce. M oreover, most Allianz subsidiaries have implemented local OHS management systems to effectively address OHS matters. These systems include OHS risk and hazards assessments, dedicated action plans to mitigate these risks, and protocols for emergency actions. Internal inspections are conduct ed and progress in reducing and preventing health issues system, established in 2024, is built along the following components for applicable subsidiaries : − Dedicated GSCA Risk Experts, responsible for OHS are identified. − Health & Safety risk assessments are conducted at least annually, covering physical safety, workplace safety, and mental health. − Action plans are defined to address medium and high risks, incl. process tracking. E1-185

Quelle est la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique ?

nan

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'information spécifique sur la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Le tableau présente les impacts cumulés à long terme (5-20 ans) sur les fonds propres selon différents scénarios climatiques. Les scénarios incluent "Net Zero 2050", "Below 2°C", "Delayed Transition", "Nationally Determined Contributions", "Current Policies" et "Fragmented World". 1. Le scénario "Net Zero 2050" prévoit des impacts positifs à moyen et long terme grâce à des politiques climatiques agressives et des progrès technologiques rapides, bien que des pertes mineures soient attendues d'ici 2050. 2. Le scénario "Below 2°C" montre des pertes cumulées relativement faibles dues aux risques de transition, mais des pertes plus importantes liées aux risques physiques à long terme. 3. Le scénario "Delayed Transition" implique des impacts faibles au début, suivis de pertes élevées après 2030 en raison d'une transition retardée et d'une reprise économique lente jusqu'en 2050. 4. Le scénario "Nationally Determined Contributions" présente des impacts similaires à court terme au scénario "Below 2°C", mais des risques physiques plus élevés à long terme en raison de l'absence de mesures politiques supplémentaires. 5. Le scénario "Current Policies" montre des impacts modérés, avec des risques physiques qui augmentent progressivement dans la seconde moitié de la période. 6. Le scénario "Fragmented World" entraîne des impacts élevés après 2030, mais moins prononcés que dans le scénario "Delayed Transition", tout en échouant à limiter efficacement le réchauffement climatique, ce qui entraîne des pertes modérées à importantes à long terme. Les scénarios "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" et "Nationally Determined Contributions" prévoient des pertes croissantes dues aux risques physiques après 2050. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Scenario Long-term 5-20 years Observations
    Net Zero 2050 0.6 The aggressive assumptions in the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario regarding the implementation of climate policies and the pace of technological progress to limit global warming to 1.5 °C result in an initial period of strong economic pressure followed by a rapid economic recovery. Positive cumulative medium- to long-term stress impacts relative to the baseline due to lower energy prices and higher energy efficiency revert to minor losses by 2050.
    Below 2°C (2.4) The orderly implementation of the policy ambition of limiting global warming to below 2 °C is associated with comparatively low cumulative losses from transition risk compared to the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario. This comes at the cost of higher losses from physical risks in the long-term due to higher global warming. In particular, an overall negative trend is predicted for the second half of the century compared to the “Net-Zero 2050” scenario.
    Delayed Transition (12.6) Very slow stress impacts materialize in initial years, followed by high cumulative own funds impacts after 2030 with the start of the delayed transition. This scenario is less ambitious than the “Below 2 °C” scenario. The stress impacts decline only slowly until 2050 due to the sluggish economic recovery in this scenario.
    Nationally Determined Contributions (3.3) In the short term, decarbonization efforts in the “Nationally Determined Contributions” scenario are similar to those in the “Below 2 °C” scenario, leading to comparable impacts from transition risks. However, the absence of additional long-term policy measures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2 °C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks.
    Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the “Delayed Transition” scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050.
    Fragmented World (9.1) High-stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the “Fragmented World” scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the “Delayed Transition” scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on this stage. However, this scenario fails to effectively limit global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. Beyond this period, the “Fragmented World”, “Current Policies” and the “Nationally Determined Contributions” scenarios are expected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts.

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente différents scénarios climatiques et leurs impacts cumulés à long terme (5-20 ans) sur les fonds propres. Les scénarios varient en fonction de l'ambition des politiques climatiques et des progrès technologiques. Le scénario "Net Zero 2050" montre des impacts positifs à long terme grâce à une transition rapide et efficace, tandis que les scénarios "Below 2°C" et "Delayed Transition" impliquent des pertes plus importantes dues à des transitions moins ambitieuses ou retardées. Les scénarios "Nationally Determined Contributions", "Current Policies" et "Fragmented World" montrent des impacts croissants liés aux risques physiques, avec des pertes modérées à importantes à long terme.

  • ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques : ### Résumé du contenu du tableau Le tableau présente les impacts, risques et opportunités liés aux questions de durabilité pour différents domaines d'activité d'Allianz : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres (y compris la chaîne d'approvisionnement). #### Impacts : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations dues aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires pour s'adapter au changement climatique. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Réduction des rendements des investissements en raison des risques physiques et de transition, affectant les actifs sous-jacents et les chaînes d'approvisionnement. - **Opérations propres** : Augmentation des perturbations opérationnelles et des coûts de conformité en raison des événements climatiques extrêmes et des réglementations liées à la décarbonisation. #### Risques :
  • Le tableau analyse les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés au changement climatique (E1 Climate change) dans quatre domaines d'activité : **Insurance**, **Proprietary investments**, **Asset management** et **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**. Résumé : - **Impacts** : Tous les domaines sont marqués comme "Material" avec un impact négatif (-). - **Risques** : Les risques sont considérés comme "Material" pour **Insurance**, **Proprietary investments** et **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**, mais "Not material" pour **Asset management**. - **Opportunités** : Les opportunités sont "Material" avec un impact positif (+) pour **Insurance** et **Proprietary investments**, mais elles ne sont pas mentionnées pour **Asset management** ni **Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)**. and

    Sustainability matters Insurance Proprietary investments Asset management Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)
    E1 Climate change
    Impacts Material (-) Material (-) Material (-) Material (-)
    Risks Material Material Not material Material
    Opportunities Material (+) Material (+)

    Le tableau analyse les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés au changement climatique (E1 Climate change) dans différents domaines d'activité : assurance, investissements propriétaires, gestion d'actifs et opérations propres d'Allianz (incluant la chaîne d'approvisionnement).
    Résumé : - Impacts : Tous les domaines sont marqués comme "Material" avec un impact négatif (-). - Risques : Les risques sont considérés comme "Material" pour l'assurance, les investissements propriétaires et les opérations propres d'Allianz, mais "Not material" pour la gestion d'actifs. - Opportunités : Les opportunités sont "Material" avec un impact positif (+) pour l'assurance et les investissements propriétaires, mais elles ne sont pas mentionnées pour la gestion d'actifs ni les opérations propres d'Allianz.

  • Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, conformément aux sections spécifiques des Annexes I et II du Règlement délégué 2021/2139. Les données sont exprimées en montants monétaires et en pourcentages pour l'année 2024, réparties entre l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM) et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - Les activités des lignes 1, 4 et 5 n'ont pas de montants ou proportions associés. - Les activités des lignes 2, 3 et 6 ont des montants faibles (0.1 à 0.3) et des proportions allant de 0.5% à 1.6%. - La ligne 7 représente la majorité des montants et proportions, avec 16.6 (97.2%). - La ligne 8 totalise les montants et proportions, avec 17.1 (100%), répartis entre CCM (17.0, 100%) et CCA (0.1, 100%). and

    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, conformément aux sections spécifiques des Annexes I et II du Règlement délégué 2021/2139. Les données sont exprimées en montants monétaires et en pourcentages pour l'année 2024, réparties entre l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM) et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA).
    - Les activités des lignes 1, 4 et 5 n'ont pas de montants ou proportions associés. - Les activités des lignes 2, 3 et 6 ont des montants faibles (0.1 à 0.3) et des proportions allant de 0.5% à 1.6%. - La ligne 7 représente la majorité des montants et proportions, avec 16.6 (97.2%). - La ligne 8 totalise les montants et proportions, avec 17.1 (100%), répartis entre CCM (17.0, 100%) et CCA (0.1, 100%).

  • Le tableau détaille les **questions de durabilité** pour quatre domaines : **assurance**, **investissements propriétaires**, **gestion d'actifs** et **opérations propres (et chaîne d'approvisionnement)**, en distinguant les **impacts**, **risques** et **opportunités**. 1. **Impacts** : - **Assurance** : Augmentation des réclamations liée aux risques climatiques physiques et aux mesures transitoires (nouvelles technologies, changements juridiques, comportements clients). - **Investissements propriétaires** : Baisse des rendements due aux risques physiques (événements climatiques) et de transition (changements technologiques, réglementaires, juridiques, comportementaux). - **Opérations propres** : Hausse des perturbations opérationnelles dues aux événements climatiques extrêmes et aux coûts de conformité réglementaire liés à la décarbonisation. 2. **Risques** : - **Assurance** : Volatilité des ratios de pertes, litiges climatiques, dommages réputationnels, et défis liés à l'abordabilité des primes. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dévalorisation des actifs due aux risques climatiques physiques et aux perturbations de transition. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue et coûts de conformité réglementaire. 3. **Opportunités** : - **Assurance** et **investissements propriétaires** : Soutien à la transition bas-carbone des clients et des investis dans le cadre de la stratégie de durabilité d'Allianz. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    ```markdown

    Sustainability matters Insurance Proprietary investments Asset management Allianz Own Operations (and Supply chain)
    Impacts Impacts Impacts Impacts
    Risks For our retail and commercial Property-Casualty business, climate change is expected to drive an increase in the frequency and severity of claims. These may be derived from both an increase in policyholders’ exposure to the physical risks of climate change as well as the consequences of transitory measures intended to mitigate or adapt to climate change, such as adopting new technologies, materials or processes with a poorly understood (insured) risk profile, legal developments, or changes in customer behavior. Especially within our Commercial business, insured parties may be subject to climate change-related litigation due to alleged greenwashing incidents, responsibility for damages due to their historical greenhouse gas emissions and other potential issues. For our Retail business, customers may require new products or coverages in response to decarbonization-related lifestyle changes; Allianz may also suffer reputational damage if our own decarbonization efforts fall short of stakeholder expectations. Some risks may be offset with premium increases, but tangential issues such as insurance affordability for customers, difficulty in pricing risks with limited historical risk data, and increased loss-ratio volatility may present challenges. Our proprietary investments may be impacted by adverse developments in investment returns due to physical and transition risks. On the physical side, decreases in investment valuations may be triggered by acute and chronic weather events; both directly in the form of damage to underlying real assets as well as indirectly in the form of disruptions to business continuity, supply chains or resource availability. Decreases in valuation may also occur solely due to an increase in investees’ exposure to physical climate change risks. On the transition side, a combination of climate change-driven changes in technological, regulatory, legal and consumer behavior may adversely impact investment performance insofar as these materially disrupt the business model of investees. This includes, for example, transition-related disruptions to the cost, quality, and availability of inputs an investee relies on to run their business; a significant increase in investees’ regulatory compliance costs or legal losses; or a decrease in customer demand for the investees’ products or services. For our own operations, an increase in extreme weather events may increase the likelihood of operational disruptions, both directly and indirectly. Decarbonization efforts are also acting as a catalyst for broad regulatory changes, including regulations impacting the insurance industry. The design and implementation of processes needed to comply will require investments in employees, external expertise, third party databases, IT systems and more. Together with an increase in operational complexity, such new regulations may drive an increase in compliance costs, business failures and operational losses.
    Opportunities Opportunities are considered material for our insurance portfolio (Property-Casualty retail and commercial) in that we are supporting our customers in their low-carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our Sustainable Solutions and low-carbon solutions. Opportunities are considered material for our proprietary investments in that we are supporting our investees in their low-carbon transition journey in accordance with our Allianz sustainability strategy and targets as part of our low-carbon solutions.

    ```

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité, et les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. - Les divulgations liées aux risques climatiques physiques (ESRS E1-9), notamment l'exposition du portefeuille de référence, la répartition des montants monétaires par risque physique, la localisation des actifs significatifs, la valeur comptable des biens immobiliers par classes d'efficacité énergétique, et les opportunités climatiques, ne sont pas pertinentes pour l'exercice fiscal 2024 en raison de leur inclusion progressive. - Les émissions de polluants (ESRS E2-4) et certaines données sur l'eau (ESRS E3-4), comme la consommation totale d'eau et le recyclage, ne sont pas considérées comme matérielles. - Les ressources en eau et marines (ESRS E3-1), ainsi que les océans et mers durables, sont jugés matériels, avec des politiques associées. - La biodiversité et les écosystèmes (ESRS 2-SBM-3) sont partiellement matériels, notamment pour le paragraphe 16 (c), avec des politiques spécifiques. - Les pratiques agricoles et terrestres durables (ESRS E4-2) sont également considérées comme matérielles, avec des politiques liées à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Disclosure requirement and related datapoint Materiality Sub-section/sub-sub-section
    ESRS E1-9 Exposure of the benchmark portfolio to climate-related physical risks, paragraph 66 Not relevant for FY 2024 (phased-in provision) Not applicable, since not relevant
    ESRS E1-9 Disaggregation of monetary amounts by acute and chronic physical risk, paragraph 66 (a) Not relevant for FY 2024 (phased-in provision) Not applicable, since not relevant
    ESRS E1-9 Location of significant assets at material physical risk, paragraph 66 (c) Not relevant for FY 2024 (phased-in provision) Not applicable, since not relevant
    ESRS E1-9 Breakdown of the carrying value of its real estate assets by energy-efficiency classes, paragraph 67 (c) Not relevant for FY 2024 (phased-in provision) Not applicable, since not relevant
    ESRS E1-9 Degree of exposure of the portfolio to climate-related opportunities, paragraph 67 Not relevant for FY 2024 (phased-in provision) Not applicable, since not relevant
    ESRS E2-4 Amount of each pollutant listed in Annex II of the E-PRTR Regulation emitted to air, water, and soil, paragraph 28 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E3-1 Water and marine resources, paragraph 9 Material Policies related to water and marine resources
    ESRS E3-1 Dedicated policy, paragraph 13 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E3-1 Sustainable oceans and seas, paragraph 14 Material Policies related to water and marine resources
    ESRS E3-4 Total water recycled and reused, paragraph 28 (c) Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E3-4 Total water consumption in m³ per net revenue on own operations, paragraph 29 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS 2-SBM-3 – E4, paragraph 16 (a) Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS 2-SBM-3 – E4, paragraph 16 (c) Material Materiality of biodiversity and ecosystems
    ESRS 2-SBM-3 – E4, paragraph 16 (d) Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS E4-2 Sustainable land/agriculture practices or policies, paragraph 24 (b) Material Policies related to biodiversity and ecosystems

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Plusieurs exigences de divulgation liées aux risques climatiques physiques (ESRS E1-9) ne sont pas pertinentes pour l'exercice fiscal 2024 en raison de leur inclusion progressive. - Les données sur les polluants (ESRS E2-4) et certaines informations sur l'eau (ESRS E3-4) ne sont pas considérées comme matérielles. - Les ressources en eau et marines (ESRS E3-1) ainsi que les océans et mers durables sont jugés matériels, avec des politiques associées. - La biodiversité et les écosystèmes (ESRS 2-SBM-3) ainsi que les pratiques agricoles durables (ESRS E4-2) sont également considérés comme matériels, avec des politiques spécifiques.

  • #### Risques : - **Assurance** : Litiges liés au changement climatique, dommages réputationnels, volatilité des ratios de pertes, et défis dans la tarification des risques. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dégradations des modèles économiques des investees dues aux changements climatiques, réglementaires et comportementaux. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue des opérations et augmentation des coûts de conformité. #### Opportunités : - **Assurance** : Soutien aux clients dans leur transition vers une économie bas carbone via des solutions durables. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Soutien aux investees dans leur transition bas carbone conformément aux objectifs de durabilité d'Allianz. #### Risques : - **Assurance** : Litiges liés au changement climatique, dommages réputationnels, volatilité des ratios de pertes, et défis dans la tarification des risques. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Dégradations des modèles économiques des investees dues aux changements climatiques, réglementaires et comportementaux. - **Opérations propres** : Complexité accrue des opérations et augmentation des coûts de conformité. #### Opportunités : - **Assurance** : Soutien aux clients dans leur transition vers une économie bas carbone via des solutions durables. - **Investissements propriétaires** : Soutien aux investees dans leur transition bas carbone conformément aux objectifs de durabilité d'Allianz.
  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques éligibles à la taxonomie mais non alignées avec celle-ci, selon différentes sections de la réglementation déléguée. Les données sont réparties en trois catégories : le chiffre d'affaires total (CCM + CCA), l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM), et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - Les sections 4.26, 4.27, 4.28, et 4.31 ne contiennent aucune donnée (montants et pourcentages à zéro). - La section 4.29 montre un montant de 0.3 avec une proportion de 0.04% pour le chiffre d'affaires total, et 0.2 avec une proportion de 0.02% pour l'atténuation du changement climatique. - La section 4.30 indique un montant de 0.1 avec une proportion de 0.01% pour le chiffre d'affaires total, et 0.0 avec une proportion de 0.01% pour l'atténuation du changement climatique. - Les autres activités éligibles mais non alignées ne présentent aucune donnée. - Le total des activités éligibles mais non alignées atteint un montant de 127.7 avec une proportion de 17.22% pour le chiffre d'affaires total, tandis que les données pour CCM et CCA sont marquées comme "n.a." (non disponibles). and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Row Economic activities Turnover (CCM + CCA) Climate change mitigation (CCM) Climate change adaptation (CCA)
    Amount % Amount % Amount %
    1 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.26 - - - - - -
    2 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.27 - - - - - -
    3 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.28 - - - - - -
    4 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.29 0.3 0.04 0.2 0.02 - -
    5 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.30 0.1 0.01 0.0 0.01 - -
    6 Amount and proportion of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activity referred to in Section 4.31 - - - - - -
    7 Amount and proportion of other taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activities not referred to in rows 1 to 6 above - - - - - -
    8 Total amount and proportion of taxonomy eligible but not taxonomy-aligned economic activities in the denominator of the applicable KPI 127.7 17.22 n.a. n.a. n.a. n.a.

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques éligibles à la taxonomie mais non alignées avec celle-ci, selon différentes sections de la réglementation déléguée. Les données sont réparties en trois catégories : le chiffre d'affaires total (CCM + CCA), l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM), et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA).
    - Les sections 4.26, 4.27, 4.28, et 4.31 ne contiennent aucune donnée (montants et pourcentages à zéro). - La section 4.29 montre un montant de 0.3 avec une proportion de 0.04% pour le chiffre d'affaires total, et 0.2 avec une proportion de 0.02% pour l'atténuation du changement climatique. - La section 4.30 indique un montant de 0.1 avec une proportion de 0.01% pour le chiffre d'affaires total, et 0.0 avec une proportion de 0.01% pour l'atténuation du changement climatique. - Les autres activités éligibles mais non alignées ne présentent aucune donnée. - Le total des activités éligibles mais non alignées atteint un montant de 127.7 avec une proportion de 17.22% pour le chiffre d'affaires total, tandis que les données pour CCM et CCA sont marquées comme "n.a." (non disponibles).

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, selon différentes sections des Annexes I et II du Règlement délégué 2021/2139. - Les montants sont exprimés en unités monétaires et les proportions en pourcentages. - Les activités alignées sur la taxonomie sont réparties entre l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM) et l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - Les lignes 1, 4, 5 et 6 ne contiennent aucune donnée. - La ligne 2 montre une proportion de 0.01 pour CCM, sans contribution pour CCA. - La ligne 3 indique une proportion de 1.92 pour CCM, sans contribution pour CCA. - La ligne 7 regroupe les autres activités alignées sur la taxonomie, avec une proportion de 98.12 pour CCM et 100.00 pour CCA. - La ligne 8 présente le total des activités alignées sur la taxonomie, avec une proportion de 100.00 pour CCM et CCA.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau détaille les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, ainsi que leur contribution au CAPEX pour l'année 2024. - Les lignes du tableau couvrent les activités économiques référencées dans les sections 4.26 à 4.31 des Annexes I et II, ainsi que d'autres activités non spécifiées dans ces sections. - Les colonnes incluent : "CAPEX Amount and proportion (2024)", "CCM + CCA Amount", "CCM + CCA %", "Climate change mitigation (CCM) Amount", "CCM %", "Climate change adaptation (CCA) Amount", et "CCA %". - Les lignes 1, 4 et 5 n'ont aucune donnée reportée pour 2024. - Les lignes 2, 3 et 6 montrent des montants de 0.1 ou 0.3 pour "CAPEX Amount and proportion (2024)" et "CCM + CCA Amount". - La ligne 7, concernant les autres activités économiques alignées, affiche un montant de 16.6 pour "CAPEX Amount and proportion (2024)" et "CCM + CCA Amount", avec des proportions de 16.6 % pour "CCM + CCA %", 2.2 % pour "CCM %" et 0.1 % pour "CCA %". - La ligne 8, intitulée "Total applicable KPI", indique un montant total de 17.1 pour "CAPEX Amount and proportion (2024)" et "CCM + CCA Amount", avec une proportion totale de 2.3 %. - Les contributions spécifiques à l'atténuation (CCM) et à l'adaptation (CCA) au changement climatique sont également détaillées, mais restent faibles en proportion. - La majorité des montants provient des activités non spécifiées dans les sections 4.26 à 4.31. - Le tableau met en évidence une faible proportion globale des activités alignées sur la taxonomie dans le CAPEX total pour 2024. and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : - Le tableau présente les montants et proportions des activités économiques alignées sur la taxonomie, ainsi que leur contribution au CAPEX pour l'année 2024. - Les activités économiques sont classées selon les sections des Annexes I et II du Règlement Délégué 2021/2139. - Les montants sont exprimés en unités monétaires, tandis que les proportions sont exprimées en pourcentage. - Les colonnes distinguent les contributions totales (CCM + CCA), celles liées à l'atténuation du changement climatique (CCM), et celles liées à l'adaptation au changement climatique (CCA). - La majorité des montants provient des activités économiques non spécifiées dans les sections 4.26 à 4.31, avec un total de 16.6 pour CCM + CCA. - Le total applicable KPI pour 2024 est de 17.1, avec une proportion de 2.3 %.

Je ne sais pas. Les documents fournis ne contiennent pas d'informations spécifiques sur la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change1 %
  • ### Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change The table compares the "Scenario," "Long-term 5-20 years" impacts, and "Observations" across six climate scenarios from NGFS/IPCC. In the "Net Zero 2050" scenario, a 0.6% impact is observed, with initial economic pressure followed by recovery due to lower energy prices and higher efficiency, leading to minor losses by 2050. The "Below 2℃" scenario shows a (2.4%) impact, with lower transition risk losses but higher physical risk losses in the long term. The "Delayed Transition" scenario has a (12.6%) impact, with low initial stress impacts followed by high cumulative impacts after 2030 due to delayed policy implementation and slow recovery. The "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenario shows a (3.3%) impact, with short-term impacts similar to "Below 2℃" but higher physical risks due to insufficient long-term policies. The "Current Policies" scenario has a (5.4%) impact, with muted stress impacts initially but moderate cumulative impacts from physical risks by 2050. The "Fragmented World" scenario shows a (9.1%) impact, with high stress impacts after 2030 and moderate physical risk losses by 2050, with increasing material losses beyond this period.
  • # --- Page 101 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement The (4) "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenario includes all pledged climate policies, even if not yet implemented. However, these policies are insufficient to limit global warming to below 2℃, leading to increasing physical risks. Accounting only for climate policies that were in place before 2022, the (5) "Current Policies" scenario is characterized by limited transition risks and high physical risks, becoming more visible over the second half of the projection period.
  • ### Section summary The Allianz Group is exposed to risks that are affected by climate change in a multitude of ways. To assess and manage climate change- related risks, we use both qualitative and quantitative strategies for climate stress testing and scenario analysis. Key risks identified for the Allianz Group include those related to proprietary investments and Property-Casualty underwriting. Stress test results based on currently available scenarios indicate that transition risks will dominate over the next 5- 10 years, while physical risks will gradually increase. We consider the stress buffers and management actions in place to be sufficient to manage these risks.
  • ### Approach Complementary to the qualitative approach, we quantify the impact of climate change on Allianz's balance sheet in a range of high- and low-emissions scenarios. In particular, we apply an integrated climate change stress test considering a limited set of risks and risk transmission channels. Results are shown in the section Climate- related risks. The stress test covers both sides of the balance sheet by measuring asset- or liability-specific stress impacts, as well as their dependencies for a static balance sheet. Impacts are assessed for market and credit stresses, as well as Property-Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stresses, using NGFS/IPCC1 scenario-based data. All entities contributing to Allianz Group's Solvency Il model are in scope for the assessment. The main focus is to provide the best estimate for own funds2 impacts.
  • ### Scenarios Allianz's business areas are exposed to climate change in different ways depending on their characteristics, e.g., different levels of exposure to physical or transition risks in different time periods. The scenarios used for the stress test therefore cover a broad spectrum of possible climatic and economic developments. This spectrum includes low-emission pathways, limiting global warming to 1.5℃ by the end of the century, and high-emission pathways, where average global warming rises up to 4℃. Short, medium, and long term time horizons up to 2050 are considered, which are equally relevant for the processes in the individual business areas of Allianz, the implementation of important political and economic strategies in connection with the Paris Climate Agreement, and the onset of increasing global warming and its negative consequences.
  • The (1) "Net-Zero 2050" scenario is determined by an orderly transition to net-zero emissions by 2050, aiming to limit global warming to 1.5℃ through stringent climate policies, causing high economic strain initially. The (2) "Below 2℃" scenario assumes an early and orderly transition to a low-carbon economy, with a less ambitious policy target to limit global warming to below 2℃ by the end of the century, with limited impact on economic growth. In the (3) "Delayed Transition" scenario, GHG emissions remain high until 2030, when strong policy measures limit warming to below 2℃. Physical risks are relatively small in the "Net-Zero 2050," "Below 2℃," and "Delayed Transition" scenarios over the 2050 time horizon. 1_IPCC: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. 152 Methodology Information and Additional Tables 2_For the purpose of the integrated climate change stress test, we estimate the own funds impacts based on the stressed MVBS excess assets over liabilities.
  • An excerpt from the aggregated stress test results is shown in table Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change,1 alongside observations at the individual scenario level2. The complete analysis covers the period from now until 2050. We show here the estimated maximum adverse impacts over the 5 - 20 year period, noting that the current NGFS scenarios are primarily aimed at modeling medium- to long-term climate-economic relationships.

Las columnas incluyen "Amount and proportion (the information is to be presented in monetary amounts and as percentages)", desglosadas en "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila 1, las actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía según la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 2, las actividades según la Sección 4.27 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 3. En la fila 3, las actividades según la Sección 4.28 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.4 (2.4% para CCM). 4. En la fila 4, las actividades según la Sección 4.29 no tienen datos reportados ("-"). 5. En la fila 5, las actividades según la Sección 4.30 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.3 (0.3% para CCM). 6. En la fila 6, las actividades según la Sección 4.31 reportan un "Turnover" de 0.1 (0.1% para CCM). 7. En la fila 7, otras actividades alineadas con la taxonomía no incluidas en las filas 1 a 6 reportan un "Turnover" de 15.5 (97.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA). 8. En la fila 8, el total de actividades alineadas con la taxonomía reporta un "Turnover" de 16.0 (100.0% para CCM y 100.0% para CCA).
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta datos sobre "Economic activities" y su alineación con la taxonomía en el denominador del KPI aplicable para el año 2024. Las columnas incluyen "Turnover" con "Amount and proportion" expresados en montos monetarios y porcentajes, desglosados en "Climate change mitigation (CCM)" y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)". Las filas enumeran actividades económicas específicas referidas en las Secciones 4.26 a 4.31 de los Anexos I y II del Reglamento Delegado 2021/2139, así como otras actividades no incluidas en dichas secciones. 1. Las filas 1, 2, 4, 5 y 6 no tienen datos reportados, mostrando "-" en todas las columnas. 2. En la fila 3, la actividad económica de la Sección 4.28 reporta un monto de 0.4 y un porcentaje de 0.1% tanto para CCM como para el total, sin datos para CCA. 3. La fila 7, que incluye otras actividades no referidas en las filas anteriores, reporta un monto de 15.5 y un porcentaje de 2.1% para CCM, 15.4 y 2.0% para el total, y 0.1 sin porcentaje para CCA. 4. La fila 8, que resume el "Total applicable KPI", muestra un monto de 16.0 y un porcentaje de 2.1% para CCM, 15.9 y 2.1% para el total, y 0.1 sin porcentaje para CCA.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre "Economic activities" y "CAPEX" en el contexto de actividades económicas alineadas con la taxonomía para el año 2023. Los datos están organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Row", "Economic activities", "CAPEX", "CCM + CCA", "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", y "Climate change adaptation (CCA)", con subcolumnas "Amount" y "%". 1. En la fila "1.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.26 no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 2. En la fila "2.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.27 muestran un "Amount" de 0.0 y un porcentaje de 0.01% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 3. En la fila "3.", las actividades alineadas con la Sección 4.28 tienen un "Amount" de 0.3 y un porcentaje de 0.04% tanto para CCM como para CCA. 4. Las filas "4.", "5." y "6." (Secciones 4.29, 4.30 y 4.31) no tienen datos disponibles ("-"). 5. En la fila "7.", las actividades alineadas no incluidas en las filas anteriores tienen un "Amount" de 14.7 (1.98%), con 13.5 (1.82%) para CCM y 0.8 (0.11%) para CCA. 6. En la fila "8.", el "Total applicable KPI" es de 741.9, pero no hay datos disponibles ("n.a.") para CCM y CCA. Notas adicionales: "n.a." indica información no disponible, y no se asignaron cuotas de alineación a objetivos climáticos o actividades nucleares/gas debido a limitaciones de datos.
  • ### Resumen de la tabla: La tabla presenta información sobre "Economic activities" y "CAPEX" en el contexto de actividades económicas elegibles según la taxonomía, pero no alineadas con ella, para el año 2024. Los datos están organizados en las siguientes columnas: "Row", "Economic activities", "Amount", "%", "Amount (Climate change mitigation - CCM)", "%", "Amount (Climate change adaptation - CCA)", "%". 1. Las filas 1 a 3 y 5 a 6, que corresponden a actividades específicas referidas en las Secciones 4.26, 4.27, 4.28, 4.30 y 4.31 de los Anexos I y II del Reglamento Delegado 2021/2139, no tienen valores reportados ("-"). 2. En la fila 4, correspondiente a la Sección 4.29, se reporta un "Amount" de 0.1 para "CAPEX" y "Climate change mitigation (CCM)", sin porcentaje asociado. 3. La fila 7, que incluye otras actividades elegibles no alineadas no mencionadas en las filas anteriores, reporta un "Amount" de 137.7 y un porcentaje de 18.3% tanto para "CAPEX" como para "Climate change mitigation (CCM)". 4. La fila 8, que resume el total de actividades elegibles pero no alineadas, reporta un "Amount" de 137.9 y un porcentaje de 18.3% para "CAPEX". No se reportan valores para "Climate change adaptation (CCA)" en ninguna fila.

Je ne sais pas. Les informations fournies ne précisent pas la proportion d'actifs exposés à un risque physique important avant prise en compte des mesures d'adaptation au changement climatique.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • stakeholders to drive the transition. 1_For further information, please refer to the Allianz Risk Barometer on the Allianz company website . Human- made climate change has already caused significant adverse impacts for nature and people. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 °C above pre -industrial levels by the end of the century. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to restrict warming to 1.5 °C, emissions need to be almost halved every decade and reach net -zero emissions by the middle of the century to maintain a reasonable chance of achieving this goal. However, if current emission trends p ersist, climate scientists estimate the greenhouse gas ( GHG ) budget will be exceeded before 2030, which necessitates urgent climate mitigation efforts from policymakers and businesses. We expect climate change will have significant impact on global stakeholders to drive the transition. 1_For further information, please refer to the Allianz Risk Barometer on the Allianz company website . Human- made climate change has already caused significant adverse impacts for nature and people. The 2015 Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 °C above pre -industrial levels by the end of the century. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to restrict warming to 1.5 °C, emissions need to be almost halved every decade and reach net -zero emissions by the middle of the century to maintain a reasonable chance of achieving this goal. However, if current emission trends p ersist, climate scientists estimate the greenhouse gas ( GHG ) budget will be exceeded before 2030, which necessitates urgent climate mitigation efforts from policymakers and businesses. We expect climate change will have significant impact on global
  • the absence of additional long -term policy meas ures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2°C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks. Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the "Delayed Transition" scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050. Fragmented World (9.1) High -stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the "Fragmented World" scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the "Delayed T ransition" scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on average. However, this scenario fails to effectively limi t global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050. the absence of additional long -term policy meas ures implies that global warming cannot be limited to 2°C, leading to a comparatively larger increase in physical risks. Current Policies (5.4) In the absence of stringent climate policy implementation, stress impacts are relatively muted, similar to the "Delayed Transition" scenario, until the second half of the time horizon where stress impacts from physical risk phase in bringing about moderate cumulative own funds impacts by 2050. Fragmented World (9.1) High -stress impacts materialize after 2030 in the "Fragmented World" scenario, but somewhat less pronounced than in the "Delayed T ransition" scenario due to less aggressive climate policy targets on average. However, this scenario fails to effectively limi t global warming, resulting in moderate losses from physical risks by 2050.
  • Beyond this period, the "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" and the "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenarios are ex pected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts. 1_The metric “maximum adverse cumulative impact on own funds” represents the worst -case cumulative stress impact that could materialize in a given scenario in the period between 5 and 20 years from today. Conclusion From the quantitative perspective, the overall cumulative own funds impacts derived from the integrated climate change stress test are considered to be within Allianz ’s risk tolerance, considering both the magnitude of the estimated losses and the time horizon over which they materialize, further underpinning the conclusion of the qualitative resilience analysis. This is particularly evident over the three- year Beyond this period, the "Fragmented World", "Current Policies" and the "Nationally Determined Contributions" scenarios are ex pected to entail even more material losses as impacts from physical risks increase and outweigh transition risk impacts. 1_The metric “maximum adverse cumulative impact on own funds” represents the worst -case cumulative stress impact that could materialize in a given scenario in the period between 5 and 20 years from today. Conclusion From the quantitative perspective, the overall cumulative own funds impacts derived from the integrated climate change stress test are considered to be within Allianz ’s risk tolerance, considering both the magnitude of the estimated losses and the time horizon over which they materialize, further underpinning the conclusion of the qualitative resilience analysis. This is particularly evident over the three- year
  • physical risk arising from the impact of temperature changes on labor productivity. Scenario variables are expanded using internal approaches to adjust regional coverage for Allianz ’s main markets and consider selected sector -specific developments. Market and credit stresses are applied to market values of assets and liabilities of in -scope entities, using a simplified approach to assess mitigation of stress impacts due to policyholder profit sharing. Scenario variables in the Property -Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stress modules are derived from hazard models based on RCPs 2.6, 4.5, 6.0, and 8.5 of the IPCC. The Property - Casualty underwriting stress module relies on projections for Average Annual Loss for a selection of the most climate change- relevant country and peril combinations. Property -Casualty underwriting stress variables are aggregated from location -specific data and applied at a country level. Property -Casualty underwriting stresses are applied to physical risk arising from the impact of temperature changes on labor productivity. Scenario variables are expanded using internal approaches to adjust regional coverage for Allianz ’s main markets and consider selected sector -specific developments. Market and credit stresses are applied to market values of assets and liabilities of in -scope entities, using a simplified approach to assess mitigation of stress impacts due to policyholder profit sharing. Scenario variables in the Property -Casualty and Life/Health underwriting stress modules are derived from hazard models based on RCPs 2.6, 4.5, 6.0, and 8.5 of the IPCC. The Property - Casualty underwriting stress module relies on projections for Average Annual Loss for a selection of the most climate change- relevant country and peril combinations. Property -Casualty underwriting stress variables are aggregated from location -specific data and applied at a country level. Property -Casualty underwriting stresses are applied to
  • Accounting only for climate policies that were in place before 2022, the (5) “Current Policies” scenario is characterized by limited transition risks and high physical risks, becoming more visible over the second half of the projection period. In the (6) “Fragmented World” scenario, the tightening of climate policy is also delayed until after 2030, as in the “Delayed Transition” scenario. However, it is fragmented globally; countries with net -zero targets may only partially achieve them, while o thers maintain current policies. Overall, action is too little, too late, and global warming rises to 2.3 °C. Both physical and transition risks are high in this scenario. The “Fragmented World”, “Current Policies”, and “Nationally Determined Contributions ” scenarios are projected to entail even higher physical risks after 2050, outweighing transition risks. The climate change scenarios used for the stress test represent Accounting only for climate policies that were in place before 2022, the (5) “Current Policies” scenario is characterized by limited transition risks and high physical risks, becoming more visible over the second half of the projection period. In the (6) “Fragmented World” scenario, the tightening of climate policy is also delayed until after 2030, as in the “Delayed Transition” scenario. However, it is fragmented globally; countries with net -zero targets may only partially achieve them, while o thers maintain current policies. Overall, action is too little, too late, and global warming rises to 2.3 °C. Both physical and transition risks are high in this scenario. The “Fragmented World”, “Current Policies”, and “Nationally Determined Contributions ” scenarios are projected to entail even higher physical risks after 2050, outweighing transition risks. The climate change scenarios used for the stress test represent
  • climate change risks for the Allianz Group relate to proprietary investments and Property -Casualty underwriting. Risks related to own operations and Life/Health underwriting are also present, albeit to a lesser extent. The following section presents the results of the integrated climate change stress test as of the fourth quarter 2024. The main focus of the stress test is to provide the best estimate for own funds impacts in Network for Greening the Financial System ( NGFS )/ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ( IPCC ) scenarios for a static balance sheet. A detailed description of the methodology is given in the sub section Quantitative assessment of climate change risks of the section Financial materiality – Risk perspective. The climate climate change risks for the Allianz Group relate to proprietary investments and Property -Casualty underwriting. Risks related to own operations and Life/Health underwriting are also present, albeit to a lesser extent. The following section presents the results of the integrated climate change stress test as of the fourth quarter 2024. The main focus of the stress test is to provide the best estimate for own funds impacts in Network for Greening the Financial System ( NGFS )/ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ( IPCC ) scenarios for a static balance sheet. A detailed description of the methodology is given in the sub section Quantitative assessment of climate change risks of the section Financial materiality – Risk perspective. The climate
  • stresses on the static fourth quarter 2024 balance sheet, without adaptation or mitigation actions from Allianz and its business partners. Impact estimates from different stress test modules are integrated based on matching global mean temperatures for 2050 between NGFS and IPCC scenarios and considering overall scenario characteristics. No diversification between market, credit, and underwriting stresses is assumed for the aggregation. The estimates of the effects of the integrated climate stress test are based on scientific research findings and scenario data that are currently available and considered relevant. They are subject to considerable uncertainties associated with long -term pr ojections in general and climate change modeling in particular. These include, for example, scientific uncertainties in the projection of hazard distributions and macroeconomic impacts in the climate change scenarios used. They are also subject to more fun damental stresses on the static fourth quarter 2024 balance sheet, without adaptation or mitigation actions from Allianz and its business partners. Impact estimates from different stress test modules are integrated based on matching global mean temperatures for 2050 between NGFS and IPCC scenarios and considering overall scenario characteristics. No diversification between market, credit, and underwriting stresses is assumed for the aggregation. The estimates of the effects of the integrated climate stress test are based on scientific research findings and scenario data that are currently available and considered relevant. They are subject to considerable uncertainties associated with long -term pr ojections in general and climate change modeling in particular. These include, for example, scientific uncertainties in the projection of hazard distributions and macroeconomic impacts in the climate change scenarios used. They are also subject to more fun damental
  • noting that the current NGFS scenarios are primarily aimed at modeling medium - to long -term climate -economic relationships. Maximum adverse cumulative own funds impacts in NGFS/IPCC scenarios relative to a baseline scenario without climate change1 % Scenario Long -term 5-20 years Observations Net Zero 2050 0.6 The aggressive assumptions in the “Net -Zero 2050” scenario regarding the implementation of climate policies and the pace of technological progress to limit global w arming to 1.5 °C result in an initial period of strong economic pressure followed by a rapid economic recovery. Positive cumulative medium - to long -term stress impacts relative to the baseline due to lower energy prices and higher energy efficiency revert to minor losses by 2050. Below 2°C (2.4) The orderly implementation of the policy ambition of limiting global warming to below 2 °C is associated with comparatively l ow cumulative losses from transition risk compared to the “Net -Zero 2050” noting that the current NGFS scenarios are primarily aimed at modeling medium - to long -term climate -economic relationships.   • the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime the reporting person. The Allianz Group has specific procedures in place to ensure that no retaliation measures such as (written) warnings, demotion, dismissal, exclusion from promotions/bonuses, or other disadvantageous measures are taken against whistleblowers, reflecting our commitment to en able a healthy SpeakUp culture within the company. Retaliation measures in any form are not accepted. Reported cases of potential misconduct are treated in strict confidentiality. In the anti- retaliation procedure, the Compliance and HR fu nctions exchange information to the extent necessary to allow identifying any potential measures that could compromise the integrity or objectivity of the investigation procedure and jeopardize whistleblower safeguarding rules. All reported incidents are assessed, documented, and managed following the internal guidelines stipulated in the Allianz Group Compliance Policy , the Allianz Standard for Anti -financial Crime
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
  • °C trajectories, ideally aligned internationally. − Sustainable finance regulation that provides a defined, science - based, and reliable framework via a common taxonomy of sustainability, clarification of asset managers’ duties related to sustainability, inclusion of sustainability in prudential regulation, and enhanced transparency of corporate reporting. Climate engagement and partnerships Since the net -zero transition is a systemic issue, it requires a whole -of- society response. Therefore, we are also seeking to join forces with other stakeholders. Our approach on the proprietary investment side builds on the work of the UN -convened Net -Zero Asset Owner Alliance, which Allianz co-founded and chaired from its inception to year -end 2024. Furthermore, we encourage companies to implement net -zero strategies via initiatives such as the Institutional Investors Group on Climate Change , Climate Acti on 100+, and the PRI .   • alone. True to our name “ Allianz ” – signifying alliance – we act as a trusted partner and collaborate with public and private sectors and civil society, contributing to systemic change toward a more sustainable future. By pooling resources, expertise, and innovation, we address these glo bal challenges together. Our involvement in the UN - convened Net -Zero Asset Owner Alliance (NZAOA) exemplifies our commitment to bridging public and private sector action to address climate change. We recognize the importance of human rights as both a value -based topic and a business issue, and we are committed to supporting and respecting the protection of human rights, in addition to ensuring that Allianz is not complicit in human rights abuses. The human rights that Allianz is committed to respecting are those agreed by governments in: SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY AND GOVERNANCE C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement alone.
