By pooling resources, expertise, and innovation, we address these glo bal challenges together. Our involvement in the UN - convened Net -Zero Asset Owner Alliance (NZAOA) exemplifies our commitment to bridging public and private sector action to address climate change. We recognize the importance of human rights as both a value -based topic and a business issue, and we are committed to supporting and respecting the protection of human rights, in addition to ensuring that Allianz is not complicit in human rights abuses. The human rights that Allianz is committed to respecting are those agreed by governments in: SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY AND GOVERNANCE C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement
S1-17

Quels sont les principaux engagements de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'Homme de ses employés ?

nan

Les principaux engagements de l'entreprise Allianz en matière de respect des droits de l'Homme de ses employés incluent :

  1. Traitement Équitable : Allianz s'engage à traiter tous ses employés de manière équitable, sans discrimination basée sur l'origine nationale ou ethnique, l'origine sociale, la santé, le handicap, l'orientation sexuelle, l'âge, le genre, les croyances religieuses ou toute autre caractéristique protégée.

  2. Santé et Sécurité au Travail : Assurer la santé et la sécurité des employés est une priorité pour Allianz, qui met en place des pratiques et des politiques pour prévenir les accidents et protéger le bien-être des employés.

  3. Liberté d'Association et Négociation Collective : Allianz soutient la liberté d'association et le droit à la négociation collective, conformément aux conventions fondamentales de l'Organisation internationale du travail (OIT).

  4. Salaires Adéquats et Conditions de Travail : L'entreprise veille à offrir des salaires compétitifs et à créer des conditions de travail favorables, incluant la flexibilité des horaires de travail.

  5. Mécanismes de Plaintes : Le mécanisme officiel de plaintes SpeakUp@Allianz permet aux employés de signaler des préoccupations, y compris des violations des droits de l'Homme.

  6. Respect des Normes Internationales : Allianz s'aligne sur la Déclaration universelle des droits de l'Homme et les conventions fondamentales de l'OIT pour soutenir et respecter les droits humains.

Ces engagements sont intégrés dans les politiques de diligence raisonnable et les pratiques de gestion des ressources humaines de l'entreprise.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety.   • In addition to the zero-tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct, the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles.   • C _ Group Management Report _ Sustainability Statement — — the International Bill of Human Rights, comprising the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and its two Optional Protocols, in addition to the core International Labor Organization (ILO) Conventions, comprising the prohibition of child labor and forced labor, freedom of association and the right to collective bargaining, occupational health and safety, and the elimination of discrimination in respect of employment and occupation.   • Positive impacts in our own operations are created through Allianz practices ensuring adequate working conditions, particularly by means of employee engagement, training, learning, and personal development. We have a strong focus on equal treatment and opportunities for all; this encompasses diversity, inclusion, and talent acquisition and retention. The health and well-being of our employees continues to be an area of focus – our practices typically include offering flexibility in working time, paying competitive wages, and fostering freedom of association and dialogue with our employees. Furthermore, securing the confidentiality of employee data is key for us. By implementing these and further practices – including annual risk assessments, as applicable, regarding the protection of human/employee rights in accordance with the GSCA – we continue to work to ensure (potential/actual) adverse impacts are prevented and reduced.   • ### END TABLE The section describes how Allianz’s commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers. ### END TABLE The section describes how Allianz’s commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers.
  • We support the principles included in the ILO core conventions on freedom of association and collective bargaining as outlined in the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations. In countries where those principles have been enshrined in local law, we fully respect and implement local rules on trade unions and employee representation. In countries that have not ratified the relevant ILO conventions, we respect the primacy of local laws and look for ways to allow our employees to organize and voice their interests to the management. Les points matériels incluent : 1. **ESRS E4-2** : Politiques sur les océans/mer et la déforestation, liées à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. 2. **ESRS E5-5** : Déchets non recyclés et dangereux, liés à l'économie circulaire et à l'utilisation des ressources. 3. **ESRS S1-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains, politiques de diligence raisonnable, prévention des accidents, et mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, liés à la main-d'œuvre propre. 4. **ESRS S1-14** : Santé et sécurité, incluant les accidents et jours perdus. 5. **ESRS S1-16** : Écarts de rémunération entre genres et ratios de rémunération. 6. **ESRS S1-17** : Incidents de discrimination et non-respect des principes directeurs de l'ONU et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE, liés aux droits humains dans la main-d'œuvre propre. 7. **ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S2** : Risques significatifs de travail des enfants ou forcé dans la chaîne de valeur. 8. **ESRS S2-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains pour les travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur. Les points non matériels incluent les risques d'incidents de travail forcé ou des enfants (ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S1) et les mesures contre la traite humaine (ESRS S1-1). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité (matériel ou non matériel), ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les points de données matériels concernent principalement les politiques liées à la biodiversité, l'économie circulaire, la sécurité au travail, les droits humains, les mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, et les écarts de rémunération. Les points non matériels sont considérés comme non applicables.

  • Le tableau présente des données sur les droits humains et la main-d'œuvre propre pour les années 2024 et 2023. Les colonnes incluent "Description", "Unité", "2024" et "2023". Les lignes sont : "Nombre de plaintes déposées par les employés via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz", "Nombre de plaintes déposées auprès des Points de Contact Nationaux pour les Entreprises Multinationales de l'OCDE", "Nombre d'incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement", "Nombre d'incidents graves relatifs aux droits humains concernant la main-d'œuvre propre", et "Montant des amendes matérielles, pénalités et compensations pour incidents liés à la main-d'œuvre propre". En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente des données sur les plaintes, incidents et amendes liés aux droits humains et à la main-d'œuvre propre pour les années 2024 et 2023. En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • Le tableau présente des objectifs liés à la gestion d'actifs et aux engagements multilatéraux pour les années 2023, 2024 et la cible pour 2030. Les colonnes incluent "2024", "2023" et "Cible 2030", tandis que les lignes sont intitulées : "Collaborer avec tous les gestionnaires d'actifs externes 'en dessous des attentes' basé sur une évaluation systématique en %¹", "Diriger ou soutenir 30 engagements multilatéraux", "Dont 15 axés sur le climat", et "Engager 15 parmi les 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés". En 2024, 95,2 % des gestionnaires d'actifs externes "en dessous des attentes" seront engagés, avec une cible de 100 % pour 2030. 15 engagements multilatéraux seront dirigés ou soutenus en 2024, dont 10 axés sur le climat, avec une cible respective de 30 et 15 pour 2030. Enfin, 5 des 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés seront ciblés en 2024, avec une cible de 15 pour 2030. Le tableau précise que l'évaluation des gestionnaires d'actifs évolue dans le temps et n'est pas une cible fixe. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Objectif 2024 2023 Cible 2030
    Collaborer avec tous les gestionnaires d'actifs externes "en dessous des attentes" basé sur une évaluation systématique en %¹ 95.2 n.a. 100.0
    Diriger ou soutenir 30 engagements multilatéraux 15 8 30
    Dont 15 axés sur le climat 10 7 15
    Engager 15 parmi les 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés 5 5 15

    ¹ Comme nous évaluons continuellement les gestionnaires d'actifs, ce chiffre n'est pas une cible fixe et évolue dans le temps.
    Résumé du tableau : Le tableau présente des objectifs liés à la gestion d'actifs et aux engagements multilatéraux pour les années 2023, 2024 et la cible pour 2030. En 2024, 95,2 % des gestionnaires d'actifs externes "en dessous des attentes" seront engagés, avec une cible de 100 % pour 2030. 15 engagements multilatéraux seront dirigés ou soutenus en 2024, dont 10 axés sur le climat, avec une cible respective de 30 et 15 pour 2030. Enfin, 5 des 100 principaux émetteurs de portefeuille non engagés seront ciblés en 2024, avec une cible de 15 pour 2030.

  • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, classés par leur matérialité ("matériel", "non matériel" ou "non pertinent") et leurs sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections. Les exigences matérielles incluent : 1. **ESRS S2-1** : Non-respect des principes des UNGPs et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE (paragraphe 19) et politiques de diligence raisonnable liées aux conventions fondamentales de l'OIT (1 à 8, paragraphe 19), dans les sous-sections "politiques Allianz ESRS" et "stratégie et modèle d'affaires liés aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur". 2. **ESRS S2-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains dans la chaîne de valeur (paragraphe 36), avec des cibles, actions et processus pour remédier aux impacts négatifs. 3. **ESRS S3-1** : Engagements politiques en matière de droits humains (paragraphe 16) et non-respect des principes des UNGPs, de l'OIT ou de l'OCDE (paragraphe 17), dans le cadre de la stratégie et du modèle d'affaires liés aux communautés affectées. 4. **ESRS S3-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 36), avec des actions et processus d'engagement avec les communautés affectées. 5. **ESRS S4-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 35), avec des actions. 6. **ESRS G1-4** : Incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin (paragraphes 24 (a) et (b)). Les points non matériels ou non pertinents incluent : - **ESRS S4-1** : Politiques liées aux consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux (paragraphes 16 et 17), jugées non applicables. - **ESRS G1-1** : Convention des Nations Unies contre la corruption (paragraphe 10 (b)) et protection des lanceurs d'alerte (paragraphe 10 (d)), avec des politiques déjà en place. and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Disclosure requirement and related datapoint Materiality Sub-section/sub-sub-section
    ESRS S2-1 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights principles and OECD guidelines, paragraph 19 Material Allianz ESRS policies
    ESRS S2-1 Due diligence policies on issues addressed by the fundamental International Labour Organization Conventions 1 to 8, paragraph 19 Material Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain
    ESRS S2-4 Human rights issues and incidents connected to its upstream and downstream value chain, paragraph 36 Material Targets, actions, channels to raise concerns and processes to remediate negative impacts on value chain workers
    ESRS S3-1 Human rights policy commitments, paragraph 16 Material Strategy and business model related to affected communities
    ESRS S3-1 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights, ILO principles or OECD guidelines, paragraph 17 Material Strategy and business model related to affected communities
    ESRS S3-4 Human rights issues and incidents, paragraph 36 Material Targets, actions, channels to raise concerns; and processes for engaging with affected communities
    ESRS S4-1 Policies related to consumers and end-users, paragraph 16 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS S4-1 Non-respect of UNGPs on Business and Human Rights and OECD guidelines, paragraph 17 Not material Not applicable, since not material
    ESRS S4-4 Human rights issues and incidents, paragraph 35 Material Actions
    ESRS G1-1 United Nations Convention against Corruption, paragraph 10 (b) Not relevant Policy(ies) are already in place
    ESRS G1-1 Protection of whistle-blowers, paragraph 10 (d) Not relevant Policy(ies) are already in place
    ESRS G1-4 Fines for violation of anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws, paragraph 24 (a) Material Confirmed incidents of corruption or bribery
    ESRS G1-4 Standards of anti-corruption and anti-bribery, paragraph 24 (b) Material Confirmed incidents of corruption or bribery

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation liées à divers aspects des droits humains, de la corruption et des politiques de diligence raisonnable. Il indique si ces exigences sont considérées comme "matérielles", "non matérielles" ou "non pertinentes", et précise les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections associées. Les points matériels incluent des politiques et des actions liées aux droits humains, aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur, aux communautés affectées, ainsi qu'aux incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin. Les points non matériels ou non pertinents concernent principalement les politiques déjà en place ou les aspects jugés non applicables.

L'entreprise s'engage fortement à respecter les droits de l'Homme de ses employés en mettant en place plusieurs mesures clés :

  1. Égalité de traitement : L'entreprise s'engage à assurer l'égalité de traitement de tous les employés, indépendamment de leur origine nationale ou ethnique, origine sociale, état de santé, handicap, orientation sexuelle, âge, sexe, croyances religieuses ou toute autre caractéristique protégée.

  2. Salaires adéquats : Elle veille à ce que ses employés reçoivent des salaires adéquats et compétitifs.

  3. Liberté d'association et négociation collective : L'entreprise soutient la liberté d'association et la négociation collective, permettant aux employés de se représenter efficacement.

  4. Santé et sécurité au travail : Des mesures sont mises en place pour garantir la santé et la sécurité des employés sur le lieu de travail.

  5. Protection des données des employés : L'entreprise accorde une importance particulière à la protection de la confidentialité des données des employés.

  6. Mécanisme de plaintes global : Le mécanisme SpeakUp@Allianz permet aux employés de soulever des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'Homme.

  7. Évaluations annuelles des risques : Des évaluations régulières des risques sont conduites pour identifier et atténuer les impacts potentiels ou réels sur les droits de l'Homme des employés.

Ces engagements démontrent l'engagement de l'entreprise à créer un environnement de travail respectueux et équitable pour tous ses employés.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels.
  • Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles. We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor Organization Convention. Our due diligence processes in own operations comply with the requirements of the GSCA, aligned with the UNGPs.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS:
  • # --- Page 79 --- ## C_ Group Management Report_ Sustainability Statement ### Human rights in own workforce Allianz recognizes the importance of human rights as both a value- based and a business issue. We see respect for human rights as a minimum standard for responsible business, both within and beyond our direct operations. For further information on our human rights commitment see our Human Rights Policy Statement.
  • ### Section summary The section describes how Allianz's commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers.
  • ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products.
  • ### Section summary Our strategy details how we manage and support our workforce with the ambition of being the top employer in the financial services industry globally. Our policies emphasize fair treatment, diversity and inclusion, and lifelong learning, all aimed at fostering an environment where every employee feels valued and respected. Our strategy involves setting clear targets for employee engagement, development, and gender and generational diversity as further outlined below. Key actions include conducting regular employee engagement surveys, offering various training programs, establishing multiple exchange forums, networks, and partnerships to promote inclusivity, and enhancing an Occupational Health and Safety Management system, as further outlined below.
  • During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standards. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the GSCA. If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights- related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement. If we identify human rights violations in our supply chain, we seek to take remedial action, in line with our ability to influence suppliers. We will sever the supplier relationship as a last resort.

Los indicadores incluyen: 1. **Reducción de emisiones propias en inversiones**: Emisiones absolutas financiadas de GHG en millones de toneladas de CO2e provenientes de corporaciones listadas, con un objetivo de **12.3 mn t CO2e**. 2. **Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)**: Porcentaje de líderes de lealtad en segmentos de negocio, con un objetivo de **50 %**. 3. **Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)**: Desarrollo contra el nivel de ambición general, con un objetivo de **77 %**. 4. **Plan de transición hacia compromisos de cero emisiones netas**: Incluye reducción de emisiones en el sector de motor retail y reducción de intensidad de emisiones en el sector comercial de Property-Casualty. 5. **Soluciones sostenibles en Property-Casualty**. 6. **Desarrollo del Digital Net Promoter Score (dNPS)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 7. **Desarrollo del Inclusive Meritocracy Index (IMIX)** contra el nivel de ambición general. 8. **Cumplimiento estricto de requisitos regulatorios y de gobernanza corporativa**, con enfoque en un sistema de gestión de riesgos adecuado y cultura de riesgos. 9. **Contribución de liderazgo**, con enfoque en atributos de personas de Allianz: Excelencia en clientes y mercado, liderazgo colaborativo, emprendimiento y confianza; evaluación multi-rater. ### END TABLE

L'entreprise s'engage à respecter les droits de l'Homme de ses employés en intégrant plusieurs mesures et politiques. Voici les principaux engagements :

  1. Évaluation et Gestion des Risques : L'entreprise réalise des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques liés aux droits des employés conformément au GSCA. Si des risques sont identifiés, des mesures préventives sont mises en place. En cas de violations, des actions correctives sont entreprises rapidement et efficacement.

  2. Protection des Droits de l'Homme : La protection des droits de l'Homme est inscrite dans les règles d'entreprise, en fonction des lois et exigences locales. Cela inclut le respect des droits internationaux de l'Homme, tels que définis dans la Déclaration internationale des droits de l'Homme et les Conventions de base de l'OIT.

  3. Outils de Retour d'Information : Des outils de retour d'information anonymes et des enquêtes permettent aux employés d'évaluer des questions comme la charge de travail, les salaires et la diversité.

  4. Égalité de Traitement : Les employés sont traités de manière égale, indépendamment de leur origine nationale ou ethnique, de leur statut social, de leur état de santé, de leur handicap, de leur orientation sexuelle, de leur âge, de leur sexe, de leurs croyances religieuses ou de toute autre caractéristique protégée.

  5. Sécurité et Bien-être : Des mesures étendues sont mises en œuvre pour assurer la sécurité physique et améliorer la santé et le bien-être des employés.

  6. Mécanisme de Plaintes : Le mécanisme global de plaintes SpeakUp@Allianz permet aux employés et à toute autre personne de soulever des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'Homme.

  7. Formation : Une formation sur les questions liées à la durabilité, y compris le traitement égal et la santé et la sécurité au travail, est dispensée à l'échelle du Groupe et des filiales.

Ces engagements reflètent une approche proactive pour protéger et promouvoir les droits de l'Homme dans les opérations de l'entreprise.

In addition to the zero -tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct , the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social orig in, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by
  • public human rights commitment, see the Allianz Human Rights Policy Statement and the Sustainability Integration Framework . While Allianz has not adopted a dedicated process to engage with value chain workers, human rights issues can be addressed through existing engagement channels. Everyone inside and outside Allianz can report issues related to the human rights of workers in our value chain through our independent complaints mechanism, SpeakUp@ Allianz , which is further detailed in the section G1 Business conduct . In 2024, no severe human rights violations of value chain workers were reported through SpeakUp@Alllianz. Adverse media screenings of potentially high -risk suppliers did not produce any information on human rights violations in our supply chain in 2024. For our insurance and proprietary investment, the ASIS process is designed to prevent Allianz from insuring or investing in public human rights commitment, see the Allianz Human Rights Policy Statement and the Sustainability Integration Framework . While Allianz has not adopted a dedicated process to engage with value chain workers, human rights issues can be addressed through existing engagement channels. Everyone inside and outside Allianz can report issues related to the human rights of workers in our value chain through our independent complaints mechanism, SpeakUp@ Allianz , which is further detailed in the section G1 Business conduct . In 2024, no severe human rights violations of value chain workers were reported through SpeakUp@Alllianz. Adverse media screenings of potentially high -risk suppliers did not produce any information on human rights violations in our supply chain in 2024. For our insurance and proprietary investment, the ASIS process is designed to prevent Allianz from insuring or investing in
  • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.

  • potential customers, individual targets have been provided to each in - scope operating entity, based on their current number of customers and potential customers noted within plan figures, excluding all customers who currently drive BEVs. This enables engagements with customers who own higher -emitting vehicles and are yet to make the transition to more sustainable mobility options. The indiv idual targets have been set in collaboration with su bsidiaries . Subsidiaries have provided their planned year -on-year customer engagements to enable progress to be tracked. When combined, they meet the Group target of 20 million engagements by 2030. The Group uses established reporting processes to track progress against these planned engagements . S1-18

Peux-tu me donner des détails sur l'approche générale de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail, pour ses propres employés ?

nan

L'entreprise Allianz adopte une approche proactive pour respecter les droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail, pour ses propres employés. Elle vise à identifier, prévenir, atténuer ou remédier aux impacts négatifs sur les droits de l'homme liés à ses activités commerciales et opérations. Cette approche est guidée par les lignes directrices de l'Organisation de Coopération et de Développement Économiques (OCDE) pour les entreprises multinationales et les Principes directeurs des Nations Unies sur les entreprises et les droits de l'homme (UNGP).

Pour ses propres employés, Allianz se concentre sur plusieurs droits humains essentiels : le traitement équitable, des salaires adéquats, la liberté d'association et de négociation collective, ainsi que la santé et la sécurité au travail. Les politiques, actions et objectifs spécifiques concernant ces droits peuvent être trouvés dans la section S1 Own workforce et sur le site internet de l'entreprise.

Allianz a mis en place un mécanisme global de plaintes, SpeakUp@Allianz, qui permet aux employés et à d'autres parties de soulever des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'homme. Ce mécanisme est largement promu via l'intranet d'Allianz et est intégré dans la formation globale sur le signalement des violations sous la loi allemande de diligence raisonnable en matière de chaînes d'approvisionnement (GSCA).

Pour plus de détails, veuillez vous référer à la section S1 Own workforce et aux documents pertinents sur le site web d'Allianz.


Afficher les sourcesLLM
Sources LLM :
  • Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets incluent "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", "E5 Resource use and circular economy" et "S1 Own workforce". Pour "E4 Biodiversity and ecosystems", les sous-sections couvrent la stratégie et le modèle d'affaires, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions et les objectifs liés à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. Pour "E5 Resource use and circular economy", les sous-sections incluent la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs et les métriques, telles que l'influx de ressources et les déchets électroniques. Concernant "S1 Own workforce", les sous-sections abordent la stratégie "Group People and Culture", la matérialité, les politiques, l'engagement, les processus pour soulever des préoccupations, les actions, les objectifs, les caractéristiques des employés, la négociation collective, le genre, les générations, les salaires adéquats, la protection sociale, les personnes handicapées, l'apprentissage et le développement, la santé et la sécurité, l'équilibre travail-vie personnelle, l'écart de rémunération entre les sexes et les droits humains. Chaque sujet est structuré pour analyser les impacts, les risques et les opportunités liés à ces domaines. and

    Le tableau présente une liste de sujets de durabilité, des exigences de divulgation associées, des sections correspondantes et des sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections détaillant les aspects spécifiques à traiter. Les sujets abordés incluent la biodiversité et les écosystèmes, l'utilisation des ressources et l'économie circulaire, ainsi que la gestion de la main-d'œuvre propre. Chaque sujet est divisé en plusieurs catégories, telles que la stratégie, la matérialité, les politiques, les actions, les objectifs, et les métriques, afin de fournir une vue complète des impacts, des risques et des opportunités liés à ces domaines.

Les exigences matérielles incluent : 1. **ESRS S2-1** : Non-respect des principes des UNGPs et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE (paragraphe 19) et politiques de diligence raisonnable liées aux conventions fondamentales de l'OIT (1 à 8, paragraphe 19), dans les sous-sections "politiques Allianz ESRS" et "stratégie et modèle d'affaires liés aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur". 2. **ESRS S2-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains dans la chaîne de valeur (paragraphe 36), avec des cibles, actions et processus pour remédier aux impacts négatifs. 3. **ESRS S3-1** : Engagements politiques en matière de droits humains (paragraphe 16) et non-respect des principes des UNGPs, de l'OIT ou de l'OCDE (paragraphe 17), dans le cadre de la stratégie et du modèle d'affaires liés aux communautés affectées. 4. **ESRS S3-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 36), avec des actions et processus d'engagement avec les communautés affectées. 5. **ESRS S4-4** : Questions et incidents relatifs aux droits humains (paragraphe 35), avec des actions. 6. **ESRS G1-4** : Incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin (paragraphes 24 (a) et (b)). Les points non matériels ou non pertinents incluent : - **ESRS S4-1** : Politiques liées aux consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux (paragraphes 16 et 17), jugées non applicables. - **ESRS G1-1** : Convention des Nations Unies contre la corruption (paragraphe 10 (b)) et protection des lanceurs d'alerte (paragraphe 10 (d)), avec des politiques déjà en place. and

Il indique si ces exigences sont considérées comme "matérielles", "non matérielles" ou "non pertinentes", et précise les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections associées. Les points matériels incluent des politiques et des actions liées aux droits humains, aux travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur, aux communautés affectées, ainsi qu'aux incidents confirmés de corruption ou de pots-de-vin. Les points non matériels ou non pertinents concernent principalement les politiques déjà en place ou les aspects jugés non applicables.

Les principales catégories incluent les travailleurs dans la chaîne de valeur, les communautés affectées, les consommateurs et utilisateurs finaux, la stratégie et gouvernance de durabilité, la matérialité, et la conduite des affaires. Les informations couvrent des sujets variés, allant de la gestion des relations avec les fournisseurs à la prévention de la corruption et des activités de lobbying.

  • Le tableau présente des données sur les droits humains et la main-d'œuvre propre pour les années 2024 et 2023. Les colonnes incluent "Description", "Unité", "2024" et "2023". Les lignes sont : "Nombre de plaintes déposées par les employés via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz", "Nombre de plaintes déposées auprès des Points de Contact Nationaux pour les Entreprises Multinationales de l'OCDE", "Nombre d'incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement", "Nombre d'incidents graves relatifs aux droits humains concernant la main-d'œuvre propre", et "Montant des amendes matérielles, pénalités et compensations pour incidents liés à la main-d'œuvre propre". En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.). and

En 2024, 388 plaintes ont été déposées via le mécanisme officiel de plaintes Allianz, et 31 incidents de discrimination, y compris le harcèlement, ont été signalés. Aucun incident grave relatif aux droits humains ou montant d'amendes n'a été enregistré pour cette année. Les données pour 2023 ne sont pas disponibles (n.a.).

  • For information on our global complaints mechanism to allow our employees to raise concerns, please refer to the section Human rights in own workforce. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) This section includes disclosures relevant to our DEI strategy, including the strategic sub-sections Gender, Generations as well as Persons with disabilities and disclosures relevant to the ESRS S1 Own workforce sustainability matter “Equal treatment and opportunity for all”. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) DEI is a core element in helping our business to fulfill and meet the needs of our equally diverse customer base. We also know that diverse teams yield better results, show higher resilience, and drive innovation and productivity. Central to achieving this is creating an inclusive culture where all our employees can be themselves and unique views are appreciated and respected. For information on our global complaints mechanism to allow our employees to raise concerns, please refer to the section Human rights in own workforce. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) This section includes disclosures relevant to our DEI strategy, including the strategic sub-sections Gender, Generations as well as Persons with disabilities and disclosures relevant to the ESRS S1 Own workforce sustainability matter “Equal treatment and opportunity for all”. DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) DEI is a core element in helping our business to fulfill and meet the needs of our equally diverse customer base. We also know that diverse teams yield better results, show higher resilience, and drive innovation and productivity. Central to achieving this is creating an inclusive culture where all our employees can be themselves and unique views are appreciated and respected.
  • Allianz aims to identify, prevent, mitigate or remediate adverse human rights impacts linked to its business activities and operations, including our supply chain. Our approach is guided by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Our due diligence in own operations and supply chains complies with the German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (GSCA) and is covered by the Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement. Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report. Allianz aims to identify, prevent, mitigate or remediate adverse human rights impacts linked to its business activities and operations, including our supply chain. Our approach is guided by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the U.N. Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Our due diligence in own operations and supply chains complies with the German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (GSCA) and is covered by the Allianz SE Human Rights Policy Statement. Please refer to the sections S1 Own workforce and S2 Workers in the value chain for further details. Our due diligence process for proprietary investments and commercial insurance can be found in the sections S2 Workers in the value chain and S3 Affected communities of this report.
  • On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery. We apply the following definition for human rights issues under ESRS: On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occupational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website. Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA.   • Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau détaille les "exigences de divulgation et points de données associés", leur "matérialité" (matériel ou non matériel), et les "sous-sections/sous-sous-sections" correspondantes. Les points matériels incluent : 1. **ESRS E4-2** : Politiques sur les océans/mer et la déforestation, liées à la biodiversité et aux écosystèmes. 2. **ESRS E5-5** : Déchets non recyclés et dangereux, liés à l'économie circulaire et à l'utilisation des ressources. 3. **ESRS S1-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains, politiques de diligence raisonnable, prévention des accidents, et mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, liés à la main-d'œuvre propre. 4. **ESRS S1-14** : Santé et sécurité, incluant les accidents et jours perdus. 5. **ESRS S1-16** : Écarts de rémunération entre genres et ratios de rémunération. 6. **ESRS S1-17** : Incidents de discrimination et non-respect des principes directeurs de l'ONU et des lignes directrices de l'OCDE, liés aux droits humains dans la main-d'œuvre propre. 7. **ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S2** : Risques significatifs de travail des enfants ou forcé dans la chaîne de valeur. 8. **ESRS S2-1** : Engagements en matière de droits humains pour les travailleurs de la chaîne de valeur. Les points non matériels incluent les risques d'incidents de travail forcé ou des enfants (ESRS 2-SBM-3 - S1) et les mesures contre la traite humaine (ESRS S1-1). and

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente les exigences de divulgation et les points de données associés, leur matérialité (matériel ou non matériel), ainsi que les sous-sections ou sous-sous-sections correspondantes. Les points de données matériels concernent principalement les politiques liées à la biodiversité, l'économie circulaire, la sécurité au travail, les droits humains, les mécanismes de gestion des plaintes, et les écarts de rémunération. Les points non matériels sont considérés comme non applicables.

  • Le tableau présente deux catégories d'activités : **activités liées à l'énergie nucléaire** et **activités liées au gaz fossile**, avec une colonne "YES/NO" indiquant si l'entreprise mène, finance ou est exposée à ces activités. Pour les **activités nucléaires** : 1. Les activités de recherche, développement, démonstration et déploiement d'installations innovantes produisant de l'énergie nucléaire avec des déchets minimaux sont marquées "NO". 2. Les activités de construction et d'exploitation sécurisée de nouvelles installations nucléaires pour produire de l'électricité ou de la chaleur, y compris pour le chauffage urbain ou des processus industriels comme la production d'hydrogène, sont marquées "YES". 3. Les activités d'exploitation sécurisée des installations nucléaires existantes pour produire de l'électricité ou de la chaleur, y compris pour le chauffage urbain ou des processus industriels comme la production d'hydrogène, sont également marquées "YES". Pour les **activités liées au gaz fossile** : 4. La construction ou l'exploitation d'installations de production d'électricité utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles est marquée "YES". 5. La construction, rénovation et exploitation d'installations de cogénération de chaleur/refroidissement et d'électricité utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles sont marquées "YES". 6. La construction, rénovation et exploitation d'installations de production de chaleur/refroidissement utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles sont également marquées "YES". and

    BEGIN TABLE

    Row Nuclear energy related activities YES/NO
    1 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to research, development, demonstration and deployment of innovative electricity generation facilities that produce energy from nuclear processes with minimal waste from the fuel cycle. NO
    2 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction and safe operation of new nuclear installations to produce electricity or process heat, including for the purposes of district heating or industrial processes such as hydrogen production, as well as their safety upgrades, using best available technologies. YES
    3 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to safe operation of existing nuclear installations that produce electricity or process heat, including for the purposes of district heating or industrial processes such as hydrogen production from nuclear energy, as well as their safety upgrades. YES
    ----- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------
    Row Fossil gas related activities YES/NO
    4 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction or operation of electricity generation facilities that produce electricity using fossil gaseous fuels. YES
    5 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction, refurbishment, and operation of combined heat/cool and power generation facilities using fossil gaseous fuels. YES
    6 The undertaking carries out, funds or has exposures to construction, refurbishment and operation of heat generation facilities that produce heat/cool using fossil gaseous fuels. YES

    Résumé du contenu du tableau : Le tableau présente deux catégories d'activités : celles liées à l'énergie nucléaire et celles liées au gaz fossile. Pour les activités nucléaires, seules les activités de construction et d'exploitation sécurisée des installations nucléaires, qu'elles soient nouvelles ou existantes, sont marquées comme "YES". Les activités de recherche et développement pour des installations innovantes produisant de l'énergie nucléaire avec des déchets minimaux sont marquées "NO". En ce qui concerne les activités liées au gaz fossile, toutes les activités mentionnées, qu'il s'agisse de la construction, de la rénovation ou de l'exploitation d'installations de production d'électricité, de chaleur ou de refroidissement utilisant des combustibles gazeux fossiles, sont marquées "YES".

L'approche générale de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail pour ses propres employés, est centrée sur plusieurs aspects clés :

  1. Protection des droits de l'homme : Les droits de l'homme sont considérés comme une norme minimale pour le traitement des employés. Des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques pour les droits des employés sont menées, et des mesures préventives sont prises en cas de risques identifiés. En cas de violations, des mesures correctives sont appliquées rapidement et efficacement (Context Num-1).

  2. Conditions de travail et égalité de traitement : L'entreprise met l'accent sur l'égalité de traitement et les opportunités pour tous, en promouvant la diversité, l'inclusion, et la rétention des talents. Elle offre des horaires flexibles, des salaires compétitifs, et favorise la liberté d'association et le dialogue avec les employés (Context Num-4).

  3. Sécurité et santé au travail : Des mesures étendues sont mises en place pour assurer la sécurité physique et améliorer la santé et le bien-être des employés (Context Num-1).

  4. Mécanismes de plainte et dialogue social : Un mécanisme global de plaintes, SpeakUp@ Allianz, est disponible pour que les employés, et d'autres, puissent exprimer leurs préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'homme. Ce mécanisme est promu à travers l'intranet d'Allianz et d'autres canaux (Context Num-3).

  5. Engagement envers les normes internationales : L'entreprise soutient et respecte les droits de l'homme internationaux tels que définis dans la Déclaration internationale des droits de l'homme et les conventions fondamentales de l'Organisation internationale du travail (Context Num-5).

  6. Lutte contre la discrimination : Allianz applique une politique de tolérance zéro envers la discrimination et s'engage à traiter tous les employés de manière égale, indépendamment de l'origine nationale ou ethnique, de la santé, du handicap, de l'orientation sexuelle, de l'âge, du sexe, des croyances religieuses, ou de toute autre caractéristique protégée (Context Num-8).

En résumé, Allianz met en œuvre des politiques et des pratiques rigoureuses pour garantir le respect et la promotion des droits de l'homme et des droits du travail dans ses opérations.


Afficher les sources Pypdf
Sources Pypdf :
  • ### Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad-hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promptly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: - The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. - Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. - Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well-being. - Training in sustainability-related issues, including equal treatment and occupational health & safety, at Group and subsidiary levels.
  • ### Section summary Our strategy details how we manage and support our workforce with the ambition of being the top employer in the financial services industry globally. Our policies emphasize fair treatment, diversity and inclusion, and lifelong learning, all aimed at fostering an environment where every employee feels valued and respected. Our strategy involves setting clear targets for employee engagement, development, and gender and generational diversity as further outlined below. Key actions include conducting regular employee engagement surveys, offering various training programs, establishing multiple exchange forums, networks, and partnerships to promote inclusivity, and enhancing an Occupational Health and Safety Management system, as further outlined below.
  • ### Strategy and business model related to workers in the value chain Allianz is committed to supporting and respecting the protection of international human rights, as well as ensuring it is not complicit in the abuse of human rights, as outlined in the International Bill of Rights and the ILO Core Conventions. This commitment also applies to our value chain. Allianz's due diligence approach to identify, prevent, and mitigate adverse human rights impacts linked to business activities has been guided by the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the UNGPs. As a multinational insurance and asset management company, our value chain encompasses workers at: - Allianz suppliers, - companies insured by Allianz, - companies that Allianz invests in as part of its proprietary investments, and - our tied agents responsible for distributing our products.
  • Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social origin, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles. We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor Organization Convention. Our due diligence processes in own operations comply with the requirements of the GSCA, aligned with the UNGPs.
  • ### Section summary The section describes how Allianz's commitment to human rights applies to the human rights and labor standards of workers in our value chain. For us, value chain workers encompass those at our suppliers, at the companies we insure and invest in, and at Allianz tied agents. For each of these stages of our value chain we have dedicated policies and actions, which are described below. They all aim to identify, assess, and mitigate risks to human rights as well as to stop and remediate human rights violations. Our complaints mechanism, NGO dialogue, and other channels allow us to engage with affected value chain workers.

We see respect for human rights as a minimum standard for responsible business, both within and beyond our direct operations. For further information on our human rights commitment see our Human Rights Policy Statement.

Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP). Los años no están especificados en el contenido. 1. **ESRS S2-1** aborda el incumplimiento de los principios de los UNGPs sobre Empresas y Derechos Humanos y las directrices de la OCDE (párrafo 19), así como las políticas de diligencia debida relacionadas con los convenios fundamentales de la OIT (párrafo 19). Se menciona la aplicación de la cláusula de salvaguarda según ESRS 2.5(e) en relación con §§ 289e y 315c HGB para la brecha salarial de género en S1-16, sin más detalles.

L'approche générale de l'entreprise en matière de respect des droits de l'homme, y compris les droits du travail, pour ses propres employés, est bien définie et proactive. Allianz considère les droits de l'homme comme un standard minimum pour le traitement de ses employés. L'entreprise réalise des évaluations annuelles et ponctuelles des risques pour les droits des employés conformément à la GSCA. Si des risques sont identifiés, des mesures préventives sont prises, et en cas de violations, elles sont corrigées rapidement et efficacement.

Allianz a mis en place plusieurs mesures pour minimiser les risques pour les droits de l'homme et les normes du travail dans ses propres opérations. Ces mesures incluent la protection des droits de l'homme intégrée dans les règles d'entreprise, des outils de retour d'information anonymes pour évaluer des questions telles que la charge de travail, les salaires, et la diversité, ainsi que des mesures pour assurer la sécurité physique et améliorer la santé et le bien-être. Des formations sur les questions liées à la durabilité, y compris le traitement équitable et la santé et sécurité au travail, sont également dispensées au niveau du groupe et des filiales.

De plus, Allianz applique une règle fonctionnelle pour la diligence raisonnable en matière de droits de l'homme dans ses propres opérations, qui couvre l'ensemble du groupe Allianz, à l'exception de certaines filiales qui sont couvertes par des normes distinctes alignées sur les principes généraux. Ces efforts sont soutenus par un mécanisme global de plaintes, SpeakUp@Allianz, qui permet aux employés de soulever des préoccupations, y compris les risques et violations des droits de l'homme.


Afficher les sources Azure
Sources Azure :
  • follow their respective definitions and do not aim to meet the definitions of any regulation, including but not limited to Sustainable Finance regulation. Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad- hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promp tly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: − The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. − Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. − Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well -being. follow their respective definitions and do not aim to meet the definitions of any regulation, including but not limited to Sustainable Finance regulation. Integrating sustainability in own operations We consider human rights as a minimum standard for the treatment of our employees. We conduct annual and ad- hoc assessments of risks to employee rights per the GSCA. If we find risks, we take preventive measures. If we find violations, we remedy them promp tly and effectively (see our Policy Statement on Human Rights). We have implemented measures to minimize risks to human rights and labor standards in our own operations. These include: − The protection of human rights is enshrined in our corporate rules, depending on local laws and requirements. − Anonymous feedback tools and surveys let employees evaluate issues like workload, wages, and diversity. − Extensive measures ensure physical safety and improve health and well -being.
  • cover topics such as working conditions, equal treatment and opportunities for all, other work -related rights, and child labor and forced labor, including human trafficking. During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standa rds. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the GSCA . If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights - related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement. If we identify cover topics such as working conditions, equal treatment and opportunities for all, other work -related rights, and child labor and forced labor, including human trafficking. During the supplier onboarding process, suppliers registered in our standard tool for procurement are asked to comply with the VCoC or to submit a comparable code of conduct. For suppliers over a defined threshold, we apply additional checks, including questions on their human rights due diligence. This mitigates the risk of engaging with suppliers who do not uphold human rights standa rds. Additional actions and processes are based on voluntary commitments as well as the requirements of the GSCA . If risks related to violations of human rights of supply chain workers are identified, we take appropriate preventive measures, including, for example, engaging with the companies in question or adding human rights - related contractual clauses to the supplier agreement. If we identify
  • Human Rights Policy Statement . On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occu pational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website . Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@ Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery . Human Rights Policy Statement . On the basis of our risk assessments, we have identified the following human rights as the most relevant for our own workforce in the context of our business model: equal treatment, adequate wages, freedom of association and collective bargaining, and occu pational health and safety. For details on our policies, actions, and targets on these specific rights, please refer to the relevant sections of S1 Own workforce and the Allianz company website . Our official global complaints mechanism SpeakUp@ Allianz gives our employees, and everyone else, the opportunity to raise concerns including risks to, and violations of, human rights. The complaints mechanism is widely promoted through the Allianz intranet and other channels, and it forms part of the global training on violation reporting under GCSA. For further information on the channel, please refer to the section Corruption and bribery .
  • development. We have a strong focus on equal treatment and opportunities for all; this encompasses diversity, inclusion, and talent acquisition and retention. The health and well -being of our employees continues to be an area of focus – our practices typically include offering flexibility in working time, paying competitive wages, and fostering freedom of association and dialogue with our employees. Furthermore, securing the confidentiality of employee data is key for us. By implementing these and further practices – including annual risk assessments, as applicable, regarding the protection of human/emplo yee rights in accordance with the GSCA – we continue to work to ensure (potential/actual) adverse impacts are prevented and reduced. All the people in Allianz own wor kforce are in scope of the Allianz CSRD DMA. development. All the people in Allianz own wor kforce are in scope of the Allianz CSRD DMA.

We support and respect international human rights as outlined in the International Bill of Human Rights and the core International Labor Organiza tion Convention. Our d ue diligence processes in own operations comply with the requirements of the GSCA, aligned with the UNGPs. For further information, please refer to the sections Integrating sustainability in Allianz own operations , Collective bargaining coverage and social dialogue , and Human rights in own workforce . If the ASPC, Group Remuneration Policy, and Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations , or single items within them are in conflict with local law or regulations, the local law or regulations will prevail. These policies are reviewed once a year taking into account legal requirements and the interests of key stakeholders such as the Allianz SE Group Centers Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by separate standards aligned with the general principles.   • workplaces. management to confirm the local implementation of the Group Remuneration Policy. In addition to the zero -tolerance policy toward discrimination included in the Allianz Group Code of Conduct , the Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations reflects our further obligations to manage risks to the human rights of our employees, including equal treatment, occupational health and safety, freedom of association, and living wages, as well as the prohibition of child and forced labor. Employees are treated equally, regardless of national or ethnic origin, social orig in, health status, disability, sexual orientation, age, gender, religious beliefs, or any other protected characteristic. The Allianz Functional Rule for Human Rights Due Diligence in Own Operations applies to the entire Allianz Group except for certain subsidiaries, which are covered by workplaces. management to confirm the local implementation of the Group Remuneration Policy.   • purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management purposes. However, we continue to monitor the evolution of the Taxonomy Regulation to cover further sectors of the economy and become a tool for portfolio steering in th e future. In addition, as part of the 2024 Taxonomy reporting, Allianz is required to disclose its exposure to the six nuclear and gas activities stipulated in the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/ 1214 ( Annex III). This disclosure seeks to elicit the portion of aligned investments that are a result of the stated activities. For 2024, Allianz ’s exposure to nuclear and gas activities is considered very small (around 3 % of aligned assets for turnover and CAPEX based on total alignment figures). The eligible tu rnover based exposure of all other objectives beside climate change is around 2 % in 2024. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management
  • Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way. Allianz took the decision to de -scope third- party asset management from E.U. Taxonomy investment reporting, in line with current market practice and our interpretation of existing regulatory requirements for 2024 reporting. The main alignment KPIs for 2024 include alignment based on turnover and alignment based on CAPEX. For our financial investments, each KPI is determined using only reported data for the investee. If, for example, Allianz has an investment in a company with a turnover alignment of 10 % and the book value of the investment is 100, Allianz would report a turnover alignment balance of 10. If Allianz has covered assets of 200, then the final alignment share based on turnover would be 10/200, or 5 %. The total alignment based on turnover additionally includes alignment shares from Allianz ’s own investment real estate held for investment, retail mortgages and renewable investments. The total alignment KPI based on CAPEX is determined in the same way.
  • be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH. be part of the fossi l fuel value chain. Beyond that, the end -use of fossil fuels is not in scope of this criterion (e.g., combustion engine vehicles or oil-fired heating systems). Thus, the DNSH criterion is automatically fulfilled for retail business, as private use is consi dered as end -use. In our portfolio screening approach, we applied the International Standard of Industrial Classification of economic activities (ISIC codes) to identify insurance policies which are not in line with the DNSH criterion as defined above: The different ISIC co des have been classified as either compliant with DNSH, not compliant with DNSH, or to be assessed on an individual customer level. We have screened our portfolios against this internal classification system. As our commercial risks are allocated to ISIC codes (or comparable national or internal classifications), we could identify insurance policies and revenues which do not comply with DNSH.
